I always understood pulleys via the perspective of the rope and distance. Probably influenced by my understanding of work in the physics sense (force * distance). To me, the intuition comes for the visual of how only half of the displacement (pull) on the rope goes into moving the object. The key point is that, ignoring friction and the mass of the rope and pulleys, the work required to lift an object a given distance remains constant, and it's a trade-off between force and distance such that increasing the distance of the pull necessarily results in less force being required.

8:54 This is wrong.

You do-not have twice the pulling force .

Why:
Very simply you are in a 1:1 configuration.
One line going out, One line going in.

This is the same as a 90° redirect.

In order to achieve a mechanical advantage you require two blocks and three lines.
Two out, One in.
Aka: two to one.

I have wanted to build an elevator to raise smallish yard equipment up into my shop loft and simply cannot afford to spend a lot of cash on the project. So if you can add snatch blocks and divide the weight by each block, that also means the holding brake would also only have the same as the lifting weight, right??  Short story: About 20 years ago I went to Indiana and bought an old Dodge. It was a few days before Xmas and a blizzard had just blown through the area and turned around and was headed back. So we had to load the car up fast. I had also bought the guys trailer that he said had all new brakes and a good winch. Well, the winch was gone and the snow was flying and his shop was surrounded by snowy grass on a slight hill.. He tried to pull the car up using a rope straight from the car to his truck. It was not working at all, but I saw that he had a few snatch blocks hanging on his tool wall and we put them to work. not only did we get the car up fast, but his truck wasn't spinning up his grass anymore!! Of course we had to drive his truck all the way across his yard, but it worked very well and we got on the road headed South pretty fast.  So what happens when you put the weight in the middle of a 6 or 8 pulley lift? Is it the same effect??

Brilliant, I love it! Before I started collecting pulleys, I got unstuck several times by myself, just pulling the vehicle out with a rope, a tree, and muscle. Use angles. Tie the rope between your object and a fixed point (tree). Pull it tight, so it is straight as possible, meaning no sag.  Then catch the rope at the midpoint, and push or pull it. You will exert incredible force!! Due to sine, cosine and tangent...this really tickles me. When the angle you make on the rope gets away from straight (180 degrees) you exert less force. Block the vehicle in place, retie the rope, and pull again. Repeat as necessary. AND!!! You can use another rope off the first one to double up...AND you can involve pulleys as the video above, creating a MONSTER! You can pull a tree over!

It's not two times the tension, it's half the tension. The net force on the load is 0 when it's suspended, and gravity hasn't changed, so since you doubled the amount of tension forces you halved their magnitude.

It's easier to pull because you only have to exert half as much force on the rope to pull the load up, since the tension is constant through the whole rope. Adding pulleys doesn't multiply the forces, it divides them.

Something that should be considered when calculating true mechanical advantage is the friction loss in the system, a modern ball-bearing climbing pulley is only about 90% efficient, a older busing pulley is only about 70-75% efficient (at best) and when you're using multiple pulleys and re-directs that significantly effects your overall mechanical advantage, a twin sheave block and tackle 4 to 1 ball bearing pulley when you factor in losses is only about a 3.1 to 1 in the end.

I was fortunate enough to have been a Mine Clearance Diver EOD, IEDD, Royal Navy, (Navy Seal) we were trained in Seamanship primarily, and then our specialisation on top, which was Air, and Mixture Gas, as well as rebreathers for special Ops. Snatch blocks were something that we would use onboard ships but did you know that you can use special knots to do exactly the same thing, but just using one length of rope..? That's when you will definatley impress someone.
Its called a Carter's Hitch, or Englishman's Trucker's Hitch. This hitch can be done as many times as you like within the length of the rope, achieving a huge mechanical advantage. This is super handy, as you can imagine.

There is a slight friction downside, but this is easily overcome by adding another hitch..

WHAT?? Your description was really confusing.  You didn't really explain what, why & how very well.  I think you should do it again but show it back to back with a lever.  A lever is more efficient than a pulley though as you don't have near the loss in friction of the pullies.  If you put a lever with a fulcrum 1/4 of the way down the lever then one side of the lever moves 4 times as far as the other side.  A pulley works exactly the same.  You pull twice as far doubling it up with a pully so you have nearly double the leverage.  With a lever you get almost exactly double depending on your fulcrum but with a pulley there is notable loss of efficiency.  If you notice when you pulled 8 lbs vs 2 lbs it was noticeably less than the actual 8 lbs.  I think if you compare it directly to a lever that people can see they will better understand what you are trying to show as I understand it but the way you described it was confusing.

Great explanation!
Try this out:
You have 100lbs of groceries at the bottom of a staircase. If you make one trip, you'd have to carry all one hundred pounds in one trip (one rope). If you make two trips, then you'd carry 50% of the groceries or 50# with each trip (two ropes) but, have to travel twice as far (2 trips vs one). Three trips is 33% of the groceries or 33# (three ropes) but, three times the distance (3 trips vs one). Four trips=25% (four ropes) etc... You reduce the load with each trip and, but have to make more trips. This obviously doesn't include resistances or calculating the weight of the pullies into the load, and other factoring forces, but it's a relatable way of understanding the basics. In Tacoma Washington we load entire ships with logs. The logs are anywhere from 2 ft to 4 ft diameter. We put them on the ship about 15 at a time they're all 20 to 40 ft long. After the logs are loaded we bring out the smash blocks and about a 1-in cable. We run the cable through all the snatch blocks. The cable can be 2 to 300 ft long. We then take the cable and tie it to the hook on the 25 to 30 ton whirley crane. You usually put 10 to 15 snatch blocks six to eight on each side run the cable through all of them with a dead head to keep one end from moving. By the time the crane has took up all the slack and actually swung around even more you can walk on the cable it's so tight in the logs are all sucked in super tight. We once had a ship that lost its balance in the ship completely turn into 45° angle completely last many tons and tons of logs on it.

OOPS! The snatch block added to your 2:1 set up loading the truck on the trailer @7:30 didn't gain you any mechanical advantage, it simply changed the direction you applied force to your original set-up. You could have attached the snatch block to the trailer where you had the rope attached and then ran the end of the rope through the snatch block then to the pickup for a 3:1 advantage. If you don't mind cutting the rope you could make a pair of 2:1 using the snatch block in a similar configuration to your original with it pulling on the original rope in place of the ratchet. The first modern, mass-production factory, was not the car-building plant of Henry Ford (as we all learned in school) but the Portsmouth Block Mill, in the Portsmouth Dockyard, of the British, Royal Navy, during the Napoleonic Wars. There they mass-produced pulley-blocks of all sorts, for the sailing ships and they did it with steam-powered, iron machinery. Each ship required no fewer than 1000 blocks and over 100,000 were eventually produced. Before this, all blocks everywhere, were hand-made, one at a time. (Thanks Wikipedia)
So the manufacture of pulleys, really pulled the world into the modern era of mass-production (Henry did the moving assembly line.)

This work multiplication is also what makes a trucker's hitch so good at ratcheting up tension. You don't actually use a pulley- you just use have direct rope-on-rope friction by putting the bitter end through the bight of the slipped half hitch- but it's the exact same principle.

I suppose technically you never need a pulley, because you can always just tie one rope through the other, but pulleys are always helpful because:

1. Any knot in a rope will weaken the rope, and
2. Pulleys reduce friction when you're pulling on the rope. Which means you don't have to pull as hard, the rope lasts longer, and just generally everything's way less likely to snap in your face or tighten irrevocably.

Early in my career I had the blessing to be stationed at, then employed by, Newport News Shipbuilding for the constructions of CVN-71 and CVN-72. Saw heavy lifts and snatch blocks, chain falls, and sheaves in action almost every day. The shipyard riggers who moved equipment and components inside the ship were skilled artisans. Later, I supervised the disassembly/reassembly of nuclear reactors for refueling. A good crane operator can make your day much less stressful. Any young mechanical or civil engineer owes it to him or herself to spend his or her summers in college at a shipyard or heavy construction site, where physics happens.

If the Jeep were in neutral, making it much easier to pull, it would also be free to roll where gravity chose, in the event of cable failure, and no one inside to apply the brakes. If you were trying a snatch by yourself. I don't mean to be a downer here, learning is great fun. Often through our mistakes, hopefully no one hurt or killed in the process. When you see a crane, and you see multiple lines, this is exactly what's happening. One thing to remember is that the loads, while limited to the size, and ability, of the crane, with radius from the center included, the loads are also limited by the strength of the wire rope (cable). Many of those cables, depending on their diameter, have pulling limitations that are around 20,000 lbs. That means, if you want to lift a lift of 100,000 lbs you'll need at least 5 lines, more like 6, which will give you 120,000 capacity, in that line pulls.

another way of thinking how this mechanical advantage works is like this: how far must i pull the rope, to get the item this distance up? When you have 4 blocks like on 4:45, to get the item 2cm up, every block must go up 2 cm, or just the last one we are using one rope (every block is connected to the next). But to get the last block to go up 2cm, the distance the rope has to travel through the first block is much greater, and it increases the more blocks you are using. so with 8 blocks, to get 2cm height increase, you may need to pull 10 cm. but that is literally the lever technique, small force over a long distance (the total useful work (W) is the same)

I believe that The reason it is easier with the snatch block; essentially using two pulleys, is because the weight is only moving half up as far as the distance you pull the rope down . When you use two pulleys, the weight only moves 1 foot up for every two foot of rope you pull down. Just like when you use a one-to-two gear ratio. It allows you to sacrifice distance moved for the amount of pressure that must be applied to the rope. That’s why people used block and tackles more than a hundred years ago. It’s thee same principal.

You video is awesome but you Jeep example is incorrect. In that example your snatch block was only a redirect and gave no mechanical advantage. It is true that for every foot the Jeep moved, the winch pulled in 2 feet of cable. The reason is because the winch is moving forward with the Jeep. At the snatch block, for every foot of cable moved on the first side there is still only 1 foot of cable moved on the other side and it remains a 1:1 ratio and no mechanical advantage. The advantage of doing this technique is that you slow the rate of pull on the stuck vehicle to reduce the strain on the winch when it is very stuck essentially just pulling half as fast without having to have a variable speed winch.

Your jeep example was a fail.
Let me explain why.

Go to back to the ladder and cinder block example, and pretend your kids are the winch.

On Example A, you have a single pulley and 3 point of contact. The winch, the pulley, and the blocks. You stated you are simply redirecting the force, which is true.

On Example B, You have 2 pulleys, and 4 points of contact. The winch, the pulley, the snatch block, and the anchor back at the top.

Now let's go back to the jeep.
You only have 3 point of contact.
The winch, the snatch block, and the jeep shackle. All you did was redirect the force so the winch could be anchored onto the jeep. The jeep still moved because it was the object of least resistance.
What you forgot to do was add the fourth point of contact that would have given you your mechanical advantage.
Had you put a snatch block on the shackle of the jeep, and anchored winch hook back to the tree, you would have gotten your advantage.

Instead of thinking about tension, think about the fact that work = force x distance. Each time you add a pulley, you're allowing the person exerting the force to move a longer distance to lift the weight the same distance. Notice in your models how every time you add a pulley the weight is lifting a smaller distance as you move your hand the same distance? This means you are able to do more work with the same amount of force, or advantageously the same amount of work with less force. This is actually the way all mechanical advantage works. Same with levers (a pry bar) same with gear ratios (the same engine can't start your car moving in sixth gear, but it can in first).

I first found theory of pulley's in my high school physics book. Teacher had skimmed that topic and no one bothered to ask much questions. Then I saw a reference question explaining compound pulley. It blew my mind on how force was being multiplied. I understood the maths, but couldn't accept on physical terms, how the force was being multiplied. I completed the how question bank on the pulleys using maths and yet couldn't understand where/how the force was being multiplied.
At this point, if I was given a pulley design, I could tell how much force multiplier would be there, but I couldn't have designed the pulley design myself. It irritated me a lot.
A few years later, when I was passing time watching clouds, somehow it clicked. It was due to the length of the rope and it's movement. That is the physical thing that is multiplying the force.

Snatchblocks are also used as fairlead blocks, to redirect a line under tension.  In this case they have zero mechanical advantage.   Great vid.  Some few technical mistakes, like put the pin of the shackle in the hook or lifting device and the slings into the bow of the hook.  Right at the end your polypropylene line lifting the two cinder blocks was rolling the pin of the shackle back and forth.  That's a no-no.  Put the pin of the shackle in the lifting device.  PLUS, snatch blocks' advantage is you can put the standing part of the line on the sheave because the cheek plate opens.  With regular blocks (like the wooden one you held up), you must reave the bitter end through the sheaves.

Great information. With such enthusiasm I suggest you buy some books on rigging "a guide for riggers" BTW @8:10 I notice bulldog grips on a zipline. The truth is this device does not have a safe working load grading. It is dangerous and should not be used for taking weights. There are no recommended torque settings for the clamping nuts. They are not for load bearing. Never use in high tension situations...crane lifts, car retrieval, or your family on ziplines (mother in law exempt)...this clamp can slip anytime if not correctly tightened and from not re-tightening regulary. A rope constrict when applying tension, this narrowing can force it to release and slip. Serious accidents can occur. If people say other wise they are wrong..a looped wire rope must be spliced or mechanically collared, tested and tagged. Bulldog clamps don't comply. Sorry but its was my job...cranes and rigging work place health and safety trainer. btw a Canadian guy was killed in northern Thailand a few years ago on a zipline due to bulldog clamps. The FBD method of explaining this never sticks. In one ear, and out the other. You should learn it, though, but you fundamentally need more analysis to do anything with it. FBD are useful to size individual components in your snatch block, for example. You don't need them at the macro level, which is what we are dealing with here. The technique that is MUCH more useful is the black box approach. You can use this technique in all sorts of problems, and is often used as a 'double check', to check your work. It's that fast. It's the first law of thermodynamics, ie energy must be conserved. For simplicity we will ignore inefficiencies, as they are tiny in comparison.

If you move a machine's inbut 2 feet, and the output responds by moving 1 foot, you have a 2:1 mechanical advantage. Power is force over a distance. The power going in is Force * 2 feet. The power coming out must be Force #2 over 1 feet.

Power in = Power out
F1 x 2' = F2 x 1'
F2 = 2 x F1.

There are two pieces of physics to understand blocks and tackles:
1) Tension (force) on both sides of a block must be equal, otherwise it would equalize.
2) Since W = F * s (where W - work, F - force, s - distance), you can do the same work by trading force for distance. For example with one block attached to the thing you're pulling and one end of rope anchored, you're using half the force, but have to pull twice as much rope to move the thing the same distance.

easy explanation, 1 pulley means equal weight, 2 pulleys divided by 2 so half the weight. Three Pulleys means you divide in half the amount of force from the last loaded pulley. Every time you add a pulley you divide by half the last loaded pulley. I feel like it’s a similar effect to changing gears in say a bike. By adding one pulley, you have to pull the rope twice as far as before ‘cuz to shorten the distance of the object to the ground by x, you’d have to “shorten” the rope the object is hanging off by x on each side of the pulley (i.e. 2x). That means the same amount of work is divided into more distance, making the work necessary for each unit of distance smaller than before, similar to how switching to a larger gear will divide the necessary work for the bike wheel to make one revolution onto a larger distance for you to pedal. Also similar to how having a larger lever will divide the work necessary to lift an object (i.e. the distance of the lever to, say, the ground) onto a bigger distance, so the absolute work necessary per degree of the lever angle stays the same but the required distance to move that degree increases so you need less force per unit of distance to the ground.

Pulley works without violating the energy conservation.
Pulley reduces the power to complete a mechanical work but does not affect total energy required to do that mechanical work.

Aha! Awesome video! One thing I learned homeschooling was that a pulley (any wheel and axel for that matter) is just a series of levers organized in a concentric way. Think of that! A wheel is actually an infinite lever with the fulcrum being the axel!!! So the same principle that applies to a lever (force vs distance) is applied on a pulley, only that the sides of the lever are always equal (and there is some added advantage by the rope gripping against the curvature of the wheel, which I don't know much about). That totally blew my mind as a child! I think you could include that in this video for us simple-machine loving people.

There's an even easier way to think about this that has helped me wrap my brain around the concept. With a single pulley, the amount you move the rope with your arm translates into the amount that the object moves. With two pulleys, the amount you move the rope with your arm is twice the distance that the object moves. It still takes the same amount of energy needed to move the object the same distance, but you're spreading out that energy with half the force required. At least that's how I understand it. Basically the same concept as leverage. When you have a long stick and you are prying an object, you are moving the end of the stick your pulling on ALOT, whereas the other end of the stick is only moving ever so slightly, but with massive force.

Say you have 2 blocks, 5 lbs each. And you want to lift it 2 feet. One pulley arranged to redirect the force to straight up vertical (1:27). You pull for 2 feet and it goes up 2 feet. Now set this up - (2:11).
Now you pull for two feet and the blocks go up one foot. You did half the work. You have to pull, less force but over more distance. Easier work but more of it. You have to pull another 2 feet to raise the blocks the second foot you want. Less force required over more distance.

It  is getting confusing with all the talk about tension in the rope, basiccaly its like you said when pulling up the car, you are trading force for distance, the amount of work always stays the same, you just need to travel more distance

hey maybe I am wrong but on the case of you trying to put the truck on the trailer the second pulley wan't used correctly. Only thing you did with the second pulley was to redirect the force and not gain leverage. You should have switched the fixed point from the trailer to the truck.
Then your first pulley should be on the trailer and then a second pulley on the truck.
In that way you gain not only the distance used by the pulleys travel but also the gain of the distance of the fixed point being move to the direction it is pulled.
Please analyse and tell me if I am right. You can verify this also be measuring the distance you need to pull, against the distance the weight is moved (you could say that it is the same concept as leverage, the bigger the leverage the furthest you have to travel it to lift the other end, gain on pulleys is based on the same concept, how much travel you sacrifice for being able to pull with less effort).
Thank you.

Come-alongs are levers and the mechanical advantage of that lever is plenty to pull a truck up a ramp which is another simple machine. Your use of pulleys with the come-along give you way too much mechanical advantage and slows you down on the side of a road, which is not a place to hang out. Mechanical advantage comes at a price. Don’t take too much.

There is such a thing called a lever. The lever has two arms, thrown over the fulcrum: on one arm of the lever, the load is usually fixed, and the load is lifted on the other arm of the lever. So the whole point of the diverter blocks is to create a fulcrum and lengthen that lever arm for which the person moving the load is holding. The law of physics - you win in strength, you lose in distance. The more outlet blocks you hang through which the rope will be threaded, the more weight you can lift.

Very good video on blocks. I would mention to be aware of the forces on your anchor point. In a simple single block system where your block is static with a rope passed thru it to a 100 object. To lift the object you add 100lbs of force. This crates 100lbs downward force on the pulling side and 100lbs downward force on the object side therefore  of creating 200lbs force on the block and whatever it is secured to. This can be a critical failure in the system if not taken into consideration.

Not sure if you do this in US, but in Russia, we tend to put some stuff (jacket will do) on the rope when we pull some heavy things like car. This will prevent the rope from flying away and cutting your face (like a whip, if it's a correct word) in case it will snap. Jacket in this case forms enough weight to compensate the wobbling of the snapped rope. This is especially important when using polyspast system (blocks) as you apply much more force to the rope.

Update: Ah, this is exactly what they do in a stuck Jeep scenario, but I haven't seen this in a first one - when towing the truck.

This is how a forklift works but in reverse, the hydraulic cylinder on a forklift pushes on what in this demonstration would be a snatch block instead of pulling on the rope end. This cuts the force in half but the forks travel twice as high as the cylinder would be able to lift them if not for the pulley it's pushing on. So a hydraulic cylinder with four tons of force would lift an object weighing two tons but twice as high.

A snatch block is akin to a transmission in a mechanical setting or a transformer in an electrical setting. The amount of energy (power) needed to perform a task is the same regardless of the number of snatch blocks used because distance X force = power, voltage X amperes = watts (power)
A snatch block reduces the force needed to move an object by increasing the distance the motor must move to do the same work. An automotive transmission and the derailleur on a bicycle are perfect examples of this.

5000 year old technology suddenly becomes exciting and trendy because a guy with phone-cam discovers it for the first time. :-)  Technically, most of the blocks you show are merely openable blocks, they are not snatch blocks. If you have to remove and replace a bolt, its not a "snatch" block. A genuine snatch block is one with an open cheek, or a built-in quick-release device so that it can be placed on and removed from the rope quickly, with one hand...like "snatching" a coin from another man's hand before he can close it. Ive sailed on square rigged ships, where the details of blocks and tackle are a minute-by-minute way of life. Snatch blocks are used on sails that have to be moved to another position quickly, and in the process their lines need to cross through another line, thus the need to detach the block, pass it around the other line, and re-attach it quickly. Typically this maneuver has to be done in a few seconds, and requires a certain amount of practice to do it well.

Very good visualization. This is a good generalization of how snatchblocks work without getting complicated. In practical use,  there are other things to keep in mind.  There will always be a certain amount of Frictional Resistance created from the sheave of the pulley. A snatch block only gets a 2:1 mechanical advantage when it's a straight " out n back" 180° pull ( minus frictional resistance) for every degree of angle wider than 180°. The mechanical advantage decreases until you're no longer adding pulling power,  you're simply changing direction.  Another key thing to remember is where the load is & how much. Simple numbers Example; use your jeep demonstration...1000lb load to move it.. run a winch cable from jeep to a snatch block anchored safely to a tree or whatever... straight back to your jeep.. yes,  2:1 advantage. Each "leg" only sees about 500lbs of load.. but the snatch block still sees the entire full load of both "legs" of the pull.. so it's critical to make sure the snatch block is rated for the entire load, not the reduced load you think you're pulling. There's so much more to using them safely,  but gotta learn the basics first.  Well done sir :)

It's interesting to note that the "work" you do to lift the cinderblocks (in the physics sense) does not change with the use of one, or more, pulleys. Work is force times distance (w = f * d). Each pulley reduces the force by 1/2 but you have to pull twice as much rope to move the block the same distance. So the work was initially f * d, but with the pulley it is 1/2 f * 2 d which is still f * d.  I expect Archimedes pulled a lot of rope to lift the war ship.  :-)

Destin - fantastic video! I often show your videos to my high school science classes. They're very entertaining and informative, and your cheerfulness always make them a pleasure to watch.
We teach all about this subject, blocks and tackles and mechanical advantage in the Royal Canadian Sea Cadets; it's a big part of seamanship. Snatch blocks (we call all pulleys "blocks" in the Navy) are especially useful in an evolution at sea called a "jackstay transfer" when we shift equipment or people from one moving ship to another.
One note about your tackles - in your examples they were all, using NavySpeak, "rigged to disadvantage" where the "hauling part of the fall" (the end you pull on, the "fall" being the rope) was pulling toward to the load. This is how we usually rig tackles since they are generally moving up and we can use our body weight when pulling down. BUT if the hauling part is rigged to pull the same way as the load is moving ("rigged to advantage"), it adds one more to the mechanical advantage. This is not magic (ofcourse). It's the same principle as a gear box. Think of a car with manual transmission. Yes, in the lowest gear it's easy for the engiene to push the car along the road. But the trade off is that the car moves very slowly. So to get the car the same distance along the road as in a higher gear the engiene must put a larger amount of revoloutions into the gearbox (with the benefit of each resoloution being easier for the engiene). But all in all the same amount of energy (ingoring a lot of other practical factors) must be used to go the full distance along the road.

The pulleys does the same. They lower the force required to lift an object, but add more string to the setup. So while it's easier to pull the string you need to pull more length of string to lift the object to the top. Resulting in the same energy being required to do the job.

They say the way to do a really hard job is to divide it up in smaller pieces. Well a pulley system lets you divide a really hard lift up in a longer string.

When they pull the Jeep in the woods the same principle/result could have been achieved if the winch had an internal gearbox set to a lower rate of power transmission (not putting the experiment down - just offering another way to look at it).

His explanation for why more pulleys make it easier to is wrong. More pulleys (or ropes) don't equal more force. The force that it takes to pull the object split by however many ropes (or tensions) in the system. There were two ropes, there wasn't 2x the force, it was that each rope (or tension) is half of what is required the pull the object.

This is a simplified version because you also have to take into account the acceleration of the system and the mass of the pulleys.

fixed roll = directing the movement to an Angle of your Choice (no leverage impact) even if you now can use your Bodyweight .
floating roll = doubles the Distance of the rope , by halving the needed force.

lifting 10KG to 1 Meter (distance to pull the rope 1m , force needed 10 kg )

adding 1 floating roll to this setup > distance to pull rope 2m ,force needed 5 kg.

and so on.

As you may guess by adding more parts to a Setup , the Grinding-force I call it increase , wich means the calculation above will help you through mid school but isn't accurate enough for Ingeneers.

Remind !! only the floating rolles work as leverage , learn to detect them (in most setups they are fix connected to the weight , and move Up/down with the weight together ;).

count them and divide the weight by their sume .

Awesome video!  I watched it this morning and went to the hardware store, picked up an extra pulley, and went out to my property where I am trying to frame a dome hut with aspen timbers.  I spent a couple hours tying anchor ropes to my temporary tall hoist pole to keep it upright under heavy loads and then I rigged up a 2:1 pulley and snatch block system to the hoist pole and my main load bearing truss which is way too heavy for me to lift.  Ran a 100 foot cable through the pulley system over to a hand crank ratcheting winch tied to a short post in the ground.  I was thinking of just using a rope through it, but I found that I still couldn't quite lift it up.   The winch worked but I should have pulled from another direction because my hoist pole started to lean away from the one side I didn't put a anchor rope, but I put a ratchet strap on it and cranked it back over.  It was still difficult to position the truss since my "crane" doesn't move.  then I got it to a point where I could release the winch and moved and used the pulley to stand the truss up and secured it with a spike.  Without the pulleys I wouldn't have been able to even get it lifted on to the walls.

The mechanical advantage results from pulleys split the lifting of the mass by the number of ropes holding the mass. A single pulley with two ropes yields a mech. advantage of 2-to-1 and requires the rope be pulled twice the distance the mass needs to be lifted. A 4-ro-1 advantage means pulling 4 times farther than the mass needs to be moved. It's leverage that reduces the effort but increases the distance. Much like a wrench that's 1-foot long will increase the leverage needed to tighten a bolt.

After thinking about this, my thinking is that pulling on something with a rope normally would concentrate all tension energy on one portion of the rope—one weak point. However, by introducing multiple energy redirections, we redistribute the pulling force onto multiple sections of the rope down the line that would not have held as much tension stress normally while also recruiting more tension strength and capability broadly. It’s similar to how shoveling something using only your upper body without your full body may prematurely exhaust your upper body, creating a choke point in your performance. Or like lifting something heavy incorrectly using your spine instead of all the muscles of your lower and upper body in conjunction—you avoid a break and snap by making the lift easier when you introduce your whole body into the lift—broadly increasingly the lifting capability and redistributing stress instead of relying on the strength of one concentrated area.

You mentioned the lift strength multiplies by a factor of the number of added tension rope segments (so 2 segments would be 2x the force). But the ratio of leverage gained is not always proportional to the number of added tension rope segments. The direction of ropes would have to remain parallel to the lifting direction throughout the movement. In the case of the car pulled onto the trailer (7:30), as the car gets closer to the trailer anchor points, the two opposing cable force becomes less parallel to the direction of the car's travel, thus requiring more applied force the more it's pulled.

I'm an engineer putting together a functional trainer, AKA pulley machine, and I watched this video to refresh my memory on how pulleys work. Great job, very practical!

[09:36] The compound pulley system, seen at the left side, has a disadvantage. The rope at the first wheel has to withstand half of the weight to lift, the next one a quarter, the next one an eighth etc. whereas at the pulley on the right side the strain to the rope is divided equally, which means the force needed to lift the weight is the strain to the rope.
Ergo: For the compound pulley system much sturdier ropes are needed than for a compact pulley system.

Destin, I Love your videos and appreciate what you do to inspire kids and others to learn about the world, BUT... I would ask that you PLEASE use and promote better safety precautions in your videos. Some of the things you do are extremely dangerous and have the potential to cause severe injury or even death to those who might attempt to replicate them on their own.

Case in point, this pulley video. You NEVER NEVER NEVER stand anywhere near a steel cable and pulley when it is under tension, Especially when it's being pulled by another vehicle. It's much to easy for something to go wrong and suffer a catastrophic failure. If any part of that system fails, it absolutely has the ability to crush bone and sever limbs. Even with ropes, you always need to know where the danger zones are and avoid them. After 30 years as a firefighter and member of a rope rescue team, I've seen first hand what can happen when things go wrong. Please be careful and please promote safety when conducting and recording your experiments. Thanks so much.

When God at first made man,

Rest in the bottom lay.

He would adore my gifts instead of me,
And rest in Nature, not the God of Nature;
So both should losers be.

But keep them with repining restlessness;
Let him be rich and weary, that at least,
If goodness lead him not, yet weariness
May toss him to my breast.”

Your favorite pully. Big homemaid are identical to pullys we had in our 1900 built barn. For a rope hay'claw' for filling the barn. It was a horse(or team of) powered lift device.

A pulley is simply a compact lever.  We know that if we can find a long lever and a fulcrum we can lift something heavy.  The heavy object moves a little and the working end of the lever moves a lot.  A lever is a machine; a force multiplier.  There is maths involved but lets not bother for now.  If you can make that very long lever shorter you can make the machine smaller and compact.  A rope is a bendy lever and the pulleys are lots of little fulcrums.  The math is always the same though where the lifting force is always proportional to the distance through which the force works.  Example: If you lift 100kg one meter into the air with 4 pulleys (in sequence) you need only 25kg load on the end but you need to pull the rope out 4 meters because 4x25=100.  Science, aint it wonderful?  Still struggling to understand?  Think of it in reverse where you have a 100kg bar balanced up in the air on a single column  That column feels a 100kg force pushing down.  If you support the bar with two columns the each feel 50kg pushing down, then 4 feel 25kg and 8 feel 12.5kg and so on.  The pulley is just pulling up by the same principle.

Isn’t there in Physics the concept of mechanical Work? Work = Force x Distance. The work performed by your hand that is pulling the rope is the same quantity as the work on the load. (That is ignoring the poulies’ weight for now) The Work necessary time lift the load’s weight can be accomplished with much less force but a proportionally greater distance. That’s how, using poulies, we can lift say a 100 pounds weight 1 meter by applying a 25 pounds force on a 4-meter pull. 100 x 1 = 25 x 4. The Work on the weight (100 x 1) will be the same Work on our hand (25 x 4). Minor point: our hands will be working in fact a bit more; they have to produce the additional Work that will move the poulies themselves, but it’s quite small compared to the task at hand.

It works the same as a transmission in a car. Lots of pulleys equals a high gear ratio aka first gear. Lots of engine revs for good torque but not much speed. Shift to second and remove some pulleys and less torque but more movement on the end for the same movement of the primary. Take away all the pulleys and just lift the blocks and that's the direct drive that most manual cars had before the advent of overdrives. The analogy falls apart at that point because while you can push overdriven gears, as you pointed out you can't push a rope. It's all a matter of leverage when you really take either example to it's most basic principles.

I believe you are mistaken about the "fixed" snatch block doubling the pull on the jeep. A fixed block  changes the direction of the pull, mechanical advantage is gained when the block is "travelling" with the load. The only pulling advantage gained with the set up on the jeep is another layer of wire rope off of the winch drum, the rating on the winch, for example 8000 lbs., is at the 1st layer of wire rope. Each added layer reduces pulling strength. I've been a towing operator for 25 years, this was taught in recovery certification classes that I attended in the beginning of my career. I worked in rope rescue for many years as a rescuer and instructor both in public and private sectors. Mechanical advantage always intrigued me. Work smarter, not harder!

My understanding of simple (vs compound) MA systems, was that to determine where the rope you're pulling on (or in the above case, the winch...or wherever the source of force originates) is attached, then add MA for every pulley that 'moves' in the system. Clear as mud? Great, lets move on. lol I much prefer your summation and practical examples of MA, and very much concur in the 'class' portion. The key to MA I always used was "moving pulleys create advantage".

For a basic foundation: if the rope is attached to a 300lb load directly you would require 300lb force (not withstanding friction, etc), and is a 1:1 ratio. However if the rope is attached to an anchor, run back through a pulley and force is applied in the opposing direction, that is a 2:1 ratio (300lb load > 150lb force). Note in the 2:1 (even numbered) the pulley at the load moves with the load toward the anchor. Force on rope attached to load will always result in an odd numbered ratio (1:1, 3:1, 5:1...); force on rope attached to an anchor will always result in an even numbered ratio (2:1, 4:1, 8:1...). To step from one ratio to the next, a pulley must move within the system. Anything that does not move only serves to redirect force - which is the whole purpose of using pulleys, but if they don't move - they don't increase the step ratio, thus reducing force necessary.

Bear in mind, this is true in a simple advantage system. When it gets into compound systems - its not so cut and dry.

So, to my question (and sorry for the lack of brevity): if my understanding of the physics is correct for simple MA systems, would your 'winch (force) > snatch block (redirect; not moving) > jeep hook (anchor)' not result in a 1:1 redirected and no gain in MA?

Admittedly I guess I was also confusing myself, I tended to throw out the hypothesis of "what if the low side pulleys were also attached to the ground, like the high side pullies are attached to the roof, and the rope terminates at the object being lifted?" which of course negates the whole point of pulleys... I.e. there's no magic in just making a rope go around wheels, you must also make the thing you're lifting rise at a different rate than the rope you're pulling.

As a kid I'd put up fence for my old man on his farm. He had grandpa's fence puller that featured two pulleys opposite each other by about 3 or 4 feet with old school hemp rope linking them and about 5 feet of pull rope. The wire would get placed in a groove with a clamp that exerted more force the more tension you applied. Hearing those pulleys creak and coming towards each other while applying a high level of tension to the wire with minimal force (from my then 90 pound frame) was amazing to watch. It also has a pulley brake system that keeps tension and automatically releases when applying pressure with the rope. (1930's tech-impressive practicality with mechanical means.) We also have a panel wire clamp and would use a pulley chained to a corner post using a tractor pulling opposite to add tension to hundreds of feet of panel. If you love pulleys, put up fence sometime.

This is a confusing way to describe pulleys. Fundamentally, the reason why a simple pulley (the one illustrated at the start of his video) cuts the needed force in half is simply because it requires you to pull the rope twice as far!

It's really no different from reducing the gear ratio on your bike by a factor of two: To move yourself the same distance, you only need to exert half as much force on the pedals, but need to move the pedals twice as far. [This is ignoring effects from friction.]

For instance, suppose you want to raise a 100 lb weight by 1/2 foot. You can exert 100 lbs. for 1/2 a foot. Or you can use a pulley system, exerting 50 lbs., but now you'll have to pull the rope by 1 foot. I.e., work = force x distance and, ignoring friction, you are raising the 100 lb weight by 1/2 foot in both cases, so you can do this using either 50 lbs. x 1 foot = 50 foot-lbs., or 100 lbs. x 1/2 foot = 50 foot-lbs.

In both cases you're doing 50 foot-lbs. or work; the pulley just allows you to do the work over twice the distance, thus halving the force you need to apply.

Hey Destin/SmarterEveryDay. I've been watching your channel a bit recently, and you shoot some awesome and fantastic videos! Keep it up.
Specifically on blocks and pulley's, if you want to see some incredible examples (and not just mechanical advantage, but amazing engineering in general) you should go sailing. On a mid sized yacht (30 - 50 ft) probably around half of the rigging uses some form of pulley system to generate a mechanical advantage. Additionally, we also use 'snap shackles' (sailing equivalent of a snatch block) under certain conditions, not to gain a mechanical advantage, but to alter the direction of force (allowing us to change the sail shape to optimise performance).
As you were saying in your video, I (at least I think) am one of those people that can look at a pulley system and instantly understand it, thanks to my sailing experience.
Anyway, maybe when the current situation dies down a bit, you could find a friend (or make a new one) to take you out sailing. As well as pulleys, there are some incredible engineering effects that take place on a sail boat. (Even though I understand it, it still astounds me that a sailboat can travel faster than the wind. :)

So by using the snatch block, you decrease the load on the winch and also pull out cable which gets the winch closer to its rating.

First up, I definitely agree that having a fundamental understanding of something is better than just stating it in words. What many people miss, however, is that words are tools used for thinking as well as communication to others. Sometimes using the right words to define and shape your understanding might be the very thing that helps you attain or maintain it in the first place.
So with that in mind, if you ever come across this comment, let me know what you think of this terminology.

Maybe it’s just me, but it seems pretty clear that the more pulleys, the slower the movement of the load. In other words, mechanical advantage isn’t magic, but simply a trade-off. In the examples in this video, load force was a limiting factor, but time (speed) and distance (of rope) were not, and trading these “non-limiting” factors for the limited one(s) results in ease, i.e. an advantage.
One of the most visible examples of this is with the block&tackle (4:00)
Look at Destin’s finger movement, then the movement of the load. More pulleys means more mechanical advantage, which transversely means less force input at any one time but also a slower movement of the load.
Another visible example is the Archimedes' compound setup (9:37)
The load of the first is the next pulley's input, and so on. So mechanical advantage is compounded, but so is the effect on distance/speed of the load.

(For anyone reading this, I’d love to hear any thoughts/responses/additions etc. in the comments below)

When hes pulling the jeep you will notice some sort of blanket layed over the winches cable. There is actually a reason for this, if the cable were to snap it is under a lot of force, and the cable will cause a lot of damage to whatever it strikes. In the event the cable snaps the weight of whatever you throw onto it will cause the cable to fall as it flails around, meaning instead of destroying your ribs or skull it would damage/break your legs. Not the best outcome but a lot better than other possibilities. Ropes under tension are no joke, people have had their heads cracked open by the rope snapping during a game of tug of war, be careful (and smart) out there friends.

A helpful way to think about this too is work. Energy lifting the object is force * distance. The energy input has to be the same as the work done to the block. The pulley just trades force for distance within that equation. I can pull twice as much rope 1/2 as hard to lift the block. I like this bc it shows how the extra pulling of the rope is not some extraneous feature, it is precisely why the pulley works.

I don't know if it's quite scientifically correct to explain the phenomenon by counting the number of ropes ("...there are two arrows [ropes] pulling up on that pulley - that's why we get twice the force...") and then casually mentioning that the load is moving a fraction of the distance of the principle rope ("I get four times the force, but I'm only moving it one-fourth as far").  That reduction of movement (actually a multiplication of force) is the REASON for the reduction in force requirement.  This might have been a better "teachable moment" as a primer for explaining how gearing works, as told by a simpler system (ropes and wheels rather than gears and numbers of teeth).  The energy required to move an object is the same by any means, but if you can double the distance over which the force is applied, you can halve the force needed.  It would have been a great segué into teaching how the gearing on the kids' bikes works, with some gears allowing multiple turns of the crank to effect one turn of the wheel.

At 4:36 you start with the 8:1 system. At 4:54 you said, "The ropes over close to me are moving a lot but the ones over near you aren't moving as much."
Also notice how the block tilts when you pull on it. Both of these things happen because the blocks are not reeved (threaded) correctly. Reeving it in this simple way causes the rope to wear out from sliding over the edge of every pulley wheel. It also ends up twisting the rope leading to twisting the blocks relative to each other. Eventually the rope will twist the blocks such that you have a mass of rope sliding against rope. Ideally you want to pull from the center of the block and end at the center of the block to minimize these problems. If you do it wrong, you can still get the rope moving up to rub against a rope moving down. When the blocks are properly reeved, they will operate at about a 45 degree angle to each other, won't tilt, won't twist the rope, and won't rub. To solve this reeving issue, a picture is worth about 10,000 words. It is not intuitively obvious. You'll have to Google it.

You don't get twice the force - rather, each rope exerts half the total force. And similar to a lever, there is a trade-off - to lift the mass the same height, you need to double the displacement (length of rope travel) for the same amount of work.

The snatch block gives you an advantage as the for whatever the force you apply the for that pulls gets doubled.

But you should also keep in mind that for whatever distance u pull the body gets pulled to Just half of the distance

It’s simple physics. Think about the forces. The force on the  cinder blocks is mass times acceleration due to gravity (mg) or its weight. The total tension of all the strings should equal that weight (mg). (Tnet)= (mg). The pulley system is a way to distribute the the tension, thus making force required to pull a lot easier. The first pulley system the force required to move the block is 1:1. Where the tension=weight. In the second with the snatch block the force required is 1:2. The tension is halved due to the snatch block which means the blocks are easier to pull up. Tension/2=mg

I always knew that pulleys re-directed force, but I never understood how that could multiply the force applied, until I realized that pulleys are really just specialized levers.  Think about it - if you put two levers perpendicular to one another, then two more between them (so they look sort of like spokes in a wheel) then pull on one end of the rope, as you pull, one lever will rotate into place, until it can no longer provide mechanical advantage, but by then, another has rotated into ITS place, and so on....

We old truckers understand this and even know who Archimedes was/is.

A couple years ago my rig was stuck trying to unload rock. There was a single, useless 3/8" chain available only because I told the company owner to get one, never imagining he'd buy something that useless for our needs.

I had the grader operator back up close to my tractor, then took the useless for every one else chain, removed the clevis, slid the chain through the toe eye mount, reassemble the clevis on the chain and then wind it 3 times around the bracket between the frame rails and around the round stock of the ripper, then through the other mount where I reassembled the clevis on the chain.

By this time everyone had walked away saying they didn't know what I was doing. Next I had the grader operator raise the ripper as high as it would go, lifting the front of the tractor and putting the same strain on each length of chain.

Got into my truck after giving the grader operator instructions.

I honked and eased out on the clutch while he eased into more load gradually and we both went forward onto a hard surface where I had him back up for slack, reversed what I'd done with the chain I then handed back to him while he shook his head.

I tried to explain doubling a chain made it a 6/8" chain and doubling that again made it a 12/8th inch chain. He didn't understand which depressed me somewhat.

Next load I pulled up to see that poor little chain lying on the ground with half hooked to a tractor and half to the grader.

None of them learned a damned thing which sorta ruined my day. It made me think of the old 1965 song by the Fugs called Wide,Wide River where the singer laments that every election was a choice of the lesser of two evils.

Nothing has changed but the names chanted by the clueless throngs.

I would have liked a physics explanation.
In simple terms (as possible)
Force is the weight we exert on something.
Work is how much force we used to move certain distance.
When we use a pulley, the 2 cords will divide the distance by 2.
Now we can exert half the force to move half the distance. Pulleys are not magic, the don't make us use less energy, we do the same amount of work but in more time; that's less potency (work done in a given timeframe.)

Some people misunderstand how pulleys work and think it's like 'free energy'. Just fyi, for instance a basic block and tackle could make the load weigh only half of its original weight, but at the same time, you're pulling twice the original span to make that happen. there are two ways to look at it
on one hand a pulley takes and give rope and you can calculate/look at how much rope is givn wehre and how far you ahve to pull your rope to pull something - then apply cosnervation of energy - if I need to pull something 4 times as far as it actually moves that means (assuming negligable friction) I need 1/4 the strength
on the other hand you can look at as ropes being under coonstant tension and transmitting that force efectively out each end when you only pull on one
which is really just a relatively simple example for one ofthe coolest things in physics: when you can look at one thing from two different perspectives and it's the exact same thing but understood and calculated from a diferent angle - linking things together like that makes some seemingly obscure things really obvious and really helps understanding things in depth

I may have missed it in the video, but an important thing to consider if it wasn't mentioned...

Work = Force x Distance (W = F * d).
(disregarding "angle" for simplicity and since I don't know how to type a theta symbol in a Youtube comment)

So it isn't really any less "work" when you are using a system of pulleys, because you are really just trading "force" for "distance". He did mention that briefly at one point when he was pulling the truck onto the trailer, but didn't go into detail.
Mechanical Advantage is a beautiful thing, but it isn't really doing any more "work". It is always just trading one component of work for another.

It would have been neat to see him mark the rope on the pulley system he was using for examples and show that he had to pull the rope twice as far to create the same amount of force, 4 times as far for 4 times as much force, 8 times as far for 8 times as much force, etc. (*not taking into consideration losses of efficiency for each component)

Needless to say, I really appreciate him and his Youtube peers for putting such great content out there for all of us... Young and Old alike.

I was taught way back when on a training ship:
Pullies do give double up, tripple up and so on.
But you have to compensate for several factors
The formular we were interduced to was something like this
m * (1+ 0.1 * X) / X+1 "(+1)"


with m being the mass
X being the total number of wheels
0.1 is to compensate for friction between wheel and line/rope, judging by this video it could easily just be 0.01 rather than 0.1 from big old wooden blocks this also helps with the SWL (save working load)
+1 is because you are always atleast splitting the load up in two.
"(+1)" is an add-on if you are pulling in the direction of travel (if you want something lifted up, you stand over it and pull upwards but then you cannot use your bodyweight. so it is often a trade off.)


Example 1.
You are lifting the cinder blocks with one block but 2 wheels because you are redirecting the force rather than pulling in the direction of travel.
(mass * 1.2) / 2
-Here you can use your bodyweight at the cost of 10% extra work from redirecting the forces.


Example 2.
You are using 8 wheels in the demonstration pullie +1 next to the weight to redirect forces.
(mass *1.9)/ 8
-You can use your bodyweight but here you almost need to overcome a lot of friction, which can make it harder.


Example 3.
To pull the truck on the trailer, you used 1 block and a truck which is pulling in the direction of travel
rather than later where it is going the oppersit way.
(mass * 1.1) / 2(+1)
-Unless it was going downhill, you wouldn't be able to use the mass of the truck, but the fact it is pulling in the direction of travel makes a diffrence.


Example 4.
The Jeep is pulling by just one wheel.
(mass *1.1) / 2

W = F (s cos F,s) or work is the product of the force and the component of the displacement, (s cos F,s), in the direction of the force (wikipedia). It's the explanation. When You use 1/10 of resulting force You need to move the rope 10x  longer distance to rise the object with F force . We can create  an equation F1*s1=F2*s2 (F2 must be greater than (mass*10N/kg) of object to even raise anything) which tells us that the force applied is inversely proportional to the length of the rope being pulled to achive the same work-energy transfer on the "heavy" side. Of course we have to add a little friction. Anyway beside the movement there is another advantage of lowering force this way - mostly the force needed to keep something lifted/steady is much lower. One pedantic note... You are confusing the term "Snatch Block"; A snatch block is simply a block that is able to be applied to a loaded line - i.e. One that has a side that moves so that you don't have restring the line.
A pulley is synonymous with block. Your big wooden block is also just a block, not a snatch block.

You're also misusing the term block & tackle; That is simply a term to reference ALL of the gear you were talking about today - it refers to all the blocks and rope/line that goes into making your pulley system. What you were calling "Block & tackle", technically is... but so was everything else you showed. What you really meant was you had two quad-blocks.
A special version of this is called a fiddle-block where a double, triple (or more) blocks are nested inside each other.


And in the case of pulling your your broken vehicle onto a trailer, you used two blocks, but you still only used 2:1 mechanical advantage because the second block did not move and was fixed in place. You just used the second block to redirect force to make it more convenient to pull.

Pulley is simple as 1 vs 1/2.

The gains on the fixed pulley are none, actually, you loose due to friction BUT sometimes it is easier to lift using your own body weight to help you out and only hold the rope once that is spent instead carry.

On a moving pulley, you basically have a radius versus diameter. Since one is 1/2 of the other you gain 50% reduced strength needed. Not exactly 50% cause of the friction and the rope weight and the pulley that is moving weight needs to be taken into account.

On multiple pulleys apply the above rules in series. So a system with 3 stationary and 2 moving pulleys would give you 1/2 * moving ones = 1/4 of strength needed which would actually result in more since moving pulleys weight, rope weight and 5 pulley friction is involved.

This is some quick math from someone who did not use them or calculated anything with them since he passed elementary physics.

Work is equal to the force applied, multiplied by the distance across which it is applied. W=F×d

By the work kinetic energy theorem, the work done on the system is equal to it's change in kinetic energy. W=∆KE

In a conservative system, for a component that itself does not lose or gain kinetic energy, the work done on that component is equal to the work done by that component. W_in=W_out

If the component is moving a different distance at one end that on the other, then the force associated will be different, since the work is the same. F_in×d_in=W_in=W_out=F_out×d_out

This means the output force is equal to the input force, times the ratio of distances. F_out=F_in×(d_in/d_out)

It is this ratio of distance that is the mechanical advantage. MA=d_in/d_out

This is how mechanical advantage works for any system: pulley, lever, gears, etc.

It's called the working factor... the formula is... the number of ropes on the movable sheaves is the working factor of the set of blocks...if 2 ropes are attached to the movable sheaves the working factor is 2:1.. if 4 are attached its 4:1  and so on .. 8 on the movable sheaves is 8:1...you get 8 lbs of pull on the movable sheaves with each 1 lb applied forse on the pull rope... hence an 8:1 working factor

I’ve been thinking on this topic lately from the standpoint of levers: weight, force, fulcrum, classes A, B, and C.
Doing the weight & balance of aircraft we calculate the weight, arm, and moment of fixed load and useful load relative to the datum and find its center of gravity relative to center of lift.
On bicycles, it’s all levers. The sprockets are like circular levers. Think of the center of the circle as the fulcrum. The radius as the lever. Shifting gears gives you a longer or shorter lever.
Same thing with pulleys. The radius is like a lever. More pulleys gives you more leverage. Distance traveled of motion when pedaling a bike, fast & easy when you downshift or slower & harder when shifting up. Now I’m wondering if there’s anything out there like pulleys with derailleurs.

With a pulley, the trade-off is distance. So, if two pulleys are used together, the amount of force required is cut in half, but twice the amount of rope is needed to be pulled to raise the object to the same desired height.

Great video. Another lesson to learn from the pulleys is measuring. Regardless which configuration of snatch blocks you are using, you can compare the pulling ropes movement to the payload's movement. In either inches or Centimeters, move the payload a fixed amount, say, 2 inches. Measure how much you moved the end of the pulling rope, say 8 inches. 8 divided by 2 equals 4. That is 4 to 1 mechanical advantage. This is usually written as 4:1. Now you're learning measuring and arithmetic.

After watching more videos about pulleys, and focussing on that you have to pull the rope further for each mechanical advantage, I understood how it works. For one rope that is attached to one pulley to move an object two meters, the rope must be pulled two meters, butt if you add another pulley that adds another point of support, the rope must then travel twice as far, because each of the two sides of the rope need to travel two meters to move the object two meters, the distance is distrbueted on bouth sides, which makes pulling the rope two meters, move the object one meter. As a retired US Coast Guard Loadmaster I appreciate you taking the time to illustrate the compounding of force available with the pully system.  I had to load heavy objects into my HC-130 taking into consideration what type of wheel (friction co-efficient), ramp angle, weight, and you guessed it just how many snatch blocks to use to safely pull the load into and then safely restrain the load in my bird for flight.  It's all about the math.  Pay attention in school kids, it will save your life.  Oh, and then for the most important part I  had to make sure it was all balanced, I scare myself now thinking years later on how easy it became I guess with lots of practice. The Biggest load I ever carried was Take Off Weight at 155,000 lbs. combined weight of cargo, aircraft, and fuel.  Hats off to my US Air Force Loadmaster instructors, they taught me well.   I survived and once even had to "save" a pilot in a hurry to die to let me do my job so he and my crew could fly another day. (Un-Balanced Load)

I’m kind of surprised you didn’t use the the physics concept of “work” in the video. The concept is clutch in my understanding of snatch blocks. Work being force over distance. It is why levers, snatch blocks, car transmissions, gear drives, drill drivers and other things work. I can lower the force if I increase the distance but still produce the same amount of work. It surprised me because it explains so many other concepts and ideas and snatch blocks are an amazing example that helped me understand all of those other ideas.

how i did learn that as a child was that any work requires a balance of power and time/distance. if you want to use less power, because you are not the hulk, then you have to invest more time/distance to get the same work done. you can either carry all your groceries at once, which requires much power to lift and carry, but less time/way cause you only have to walk once. or you do split the groceries into smaller packets, then you need much less power to lift and carry each packet, but you have to make the way more often using more time/distance to finish the job.

same here. you can either pull the same distance down that you would need to lift something up, which requires the maximum of power or you add more string, so you pull more down which needs more time/distance aka rope length, but also way less power to do so.

because in the end its the same result. walk 10 times with each 1kg is the same work as walking 1 time with 10kg.

The most common misconception is you can increase force with only 1 snatch block, You need at least 2 to do that, The first snatch block can redirect the line,, but it cannot increase the force being applied, If you add a second snatch block you have a 2:1 ratio so it takes 2 feet to move something 1 foot but it has multiplied the force by two.

Destin I loved your video but I wanted to point out a few things about using pulleys to create mechanical advantage. Before you can determine the amount of mechanical advantage being created, you have to determine if it is an odd or an even system by looking at the terminal end of the rope. Only then can you count the number of moving lines to determine the mechanical advantage of the system. If the terminal end of the rope is at the anchor (pulley demonstration at 4:08) then you have created an even system like the 4:1 demonstrated. However, if the terminal end of the rope is at the load (Jeep at 8:26) you have created an odd system; unfortunately you didn’t create any mechanical advantage with the Jeep because the pulley you inserted acted only as a change of direction. With that being said, a change of direction can be useful (as demonstrated by your kids at 1:21) but it creates no mechanical advantage. Additionally, the second pulley you inserted into the system when moving the pickup onto the trailer was also simply a change of direction with no mechanical advantage added. However, with the same number of pulleys, you could have “flipped” the system so the terminal end of the rope was on the front of the truck. Then run the rope to a pulley on the front of the trailer and back to a pulley on the front of the truck. Now, since the terminal end is at the load, you have an odd system with a 3:1 mechanical advantage. This is colloquially called a Z drag because the ropes form a Z pattern when laid out. Physically described, the pullies correspond to a single-lever jack. One of the two ratios is a single-armed lever. This means that the lever arm is twice as long as the load arm. This results from the geometry of the pulley, as the lever is the pivot point on the load side of the wheel, the center of gravity is on the axle and the point of pull is on the drawn rope side. (writen down it seems quite  complicated enough). Of course, this only applies to moving pullies, the fixed one only reverses the direction of force.

On the clip itself: thoroughly enjoyable, especially the involvement of all the nice people.

On safety (and summing up what several have said): safety in the work environment or at home is a matter of common sense. There's a tendency to get carried away by the excitement of getting something to work and to overlook that.

Always think about what might happen if the system you've designed or built -- mechanical or electrical -- failed ... and incorporate in to the design a means of mitigating the failure: the fabric draped over the cables is an example.

Above all -- in relation to lines and cables -- never stand in the vicinity of one under stress (load): when it fails, you will NOT have time to get out of the way.

So works under sort of the same consept of gearing where you trade number of rotations for force, but now you are trading how far you have to pull the rope to pull the lifted object, but it's more versatile because you don't have to have a direct contention gear to gear, you could do exactly the same thing with a gear, but it would be more awkward to apply to an unplanned scenario. Obviously gears have there place as you are not limited by the ropes as to how many turns you can do.

So you couldn't use pulleys in a car for example, but the reverse is true that theoretically you could do everything to can do with pulleys with gears, I am 29 and almost 30 and didn't know how pulleys worked...

Ask any wrecker driver or crane operator and they will tell you that snatch blocks work and are used in their everyday operations.  Years ago, I quizzed a physicist about the principle behind how these pulleys and blocks work and was told it has to do with the Law of Conservation of Energy.  With each line extended and returned, you half the line speed, thus increasing the effort of your pulling force resulting in the "conservation of energy". Personally, raised to vertical a 50,000# well drill that had been turned over on its side (30 foot tall derrick was raised and pinned in place at the time). Did this with a 10,000# rated hydraulic winch and (you guessed it) several snatch blocks.  It definitely works and quite well!
PS. Snatch Blocks are on sale at Harbor Freight for about $20/each through end of year. Great price for what you get!!

I love watching these videos!... I actually like to pause it as soon as you have the experiment set up and think through what's happening before playing it to hear the explanation. In the first segment, when you are using a single snatch block with the ladder and cinder blocks, what I thought up is this: force applied over a certain distance. You have to pull the rope the total length of all the rope used to lift the blocks only half that distance. You have to think about how far the load is traveling and divide that by the length of rope you must pull to raise the load.

Also a little fun fact, you can also lift much heavier objects, even if they exceed the rope's rated strength. Because if you have multiple segments of rope running between sets of pulleys, the weight of the load is divided evenly between them, a 100 pound load divided among 10 segments of rope puts only 10 pounds of weight on each segment, even though it's all in the same continuous piece of rope, no single point of the rope is being subjected to more than 10 pounds of pull.

When you're trying to get the car on the trailer, you rig a 2:1. Then the guy comes along and uses his car to pull on that 2:1. Then you reeve an additional pulley tied at the anchor and have the car pull it the other direction. Okay fine, but that additional pulley did not actually create additional mechanical advantage, because rule 3 of simple systems tells us that, if the final pulley is tied at the anchor (the trailer in this case), then it's a change of direction only, and creates no additional advantage. You can double check that by counting units of tension in both.

A few points to add. In the 4 to 1 system you have it is worth noting that your overhead anchor point will see 5 times the force you are putting on the rope. Example, you pulled with 2 pounds on the rope and had 8 pounds of lift. Your top anchor was experiencing 10 lb of pull down. On the same principle Your 4 to 1 can become a 5 to 1 if you flip it over and lift up on the hand line.  Additionally, when winching with the Jeep your anchor tree was seeing twice your winch pull capability. Important to make sure all your rigging slings, shackles, and other hardware can handle the load of these things.

Hey Destin, I noticed at 9:00 that there was a blanket on the tow straps. I didn't think anything of it and don't recall you mentioning it as a safety practice. But today, my work colleagues mentioned putting a weight, blanket or other object on tow straps or ropes when using them to pull things because if the strap fails, the hook snaps or other failure occurs, the weight on the rope/strap will reduce the chance of injury from a flying rope, metal hook, tree part, etc. It dampens the "snap." Thought it was worth mentioning.

One problem with compound pulleys is that you need to pull the rope longer. If the force is reduced by 8 times then you need to pull the rope 8 times more.

As awesome as snatch blocks are,  there is a drawback: for every multiplication of force, there is an equal multiplication of cable length required to pull it. So you may be able to setup 12 snatch blocks, but for every foot you pull on your cable, only moves the load an inch. Great video!

Cool commercial. The "tension" is actually divided by the number of lines. The force multiplication is due to the distance you have to pull per distance the load moves. If you have only the rope (0 or 1 pulley's = 1 line) the load moves 1" for every 1" you pull the rope. Add a second pulley = 2 lines now every 1" you pull rope the load moves 1/2" (that is the pull" / # lines). Add a third pulley and thus a third line and 1" pull = 1/3" load move. You can probably run the pulleys in different configurations that would change the ratios but that is the basis. Newtons law of Conservation of Energy realize that the amount of energy or work that you put into a system is what you get out - losses in the form of sound, heat and light.
So back to the example: if you have 2 lines it takes 2x the steps to move the load the same distance as it does with the 1 line. Since the load is moved the same distance, it takes the same amount of energy or work to move it. An example is the difference between walking up steep steps vs. a ramp. The stairs might be half the length and thus half the steps as the ramp but the ramp is easier to walk up. But once you get to the top of the stairs and your friend to the top of the ramp both will have exerted the same amount of energy.

The snatch block is half the equation, and the more popularly explored one.  When you had to pull your jeep out or pull your truck onto a flatbed, you were actually very lucky.  You had a solid point to anchor to in both cases.  The lesser explored half is the dead man.  A device that you can deploy to pull against.  I recently had to move an old tractor and there was nothing to pull against anywhere near where I wanted it to wind up.  My first attempt was a simple post driven into the ground and my come along in it's snatch block mode.  The post tipped over before the tractor started to move.  I welded up a more proper dead man, which went no further in the ground than the post, and I started cranking on the come along.  The dead man creaked a bit, but the tractor moved.  I can see the dead man is going to be a handy thing to have around.  You may want to consider making a video on dead men, and how they work.

Good old force vs speed = power. Same in vehicle performance. Torque x speed = power. 100lbft torque at 100rpm isn't an awful lot. Do that same torque at 100,000 and you've got yourself nearly 2000 horse power. The power required to move an object is the same - it just depends on speed. Higher power = faster movement. Lower power, reduce the speed and up the torque and get it done slower. But the amount of watts required to do it will be the same (assuming identical efficiency).

For early explanation to students (and adults who didn't pay attention in school), I tell them to forget pulleys for the moment and picture a 200 lbs cube hung from the ceiling by four ropes. Ropes are connected to each corner of the top and are under equal tensions. The students intuitively understand that each rope carries 50 lbs of weight. Now bring in a diagram or model of a block and tackle or series of pulleys that have four supporting lines and they make the connection. Of course, you may have to convince them that in a typical setup the line going down to someone doing the pulling is not a supporting line, it just changes the direction of the force. (you could have the person on a platform above pulling upwards which makes it a supporting line and one less pulley is needed)
Of course, explaining the compound pulley system in the later part of video may take more discussion...

You did a lot of talking but you didn't actually explain how pulleys work. You didn't even properly demonstrate how the rope works through a pulley. (You came close with the rope tension but even that was off and body weight isn't why a pulley works.). Basically Newton's Third Law: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction. ie. In a single pulley system when you exert 100lbs of pressure on one side of the pulley it exerts 100lbs of pressure on the other side of the pulley. (assuming 180 degree bend and 100% efficient pulley). This gives you in effect 200lbs of pulling force and has the added side effect of putting 200lbs of pressure upon your pulley and it's attachment point. It's similar to how a lever works. By reducing the distance travelled you've reduced the amount of force required.

Work in = Work out
Work is equal to Force multiplied by distance. Work done by pulley is work multiplied by height
