What always confused me about pulleys is exactly HOW they multiply the force applied to them.  Then I realized that they are essentially just levers, used in class 2 configuration.  Imagine the side of the pulley that is anchored to the static rope as the fulcrum.  The other side is where the force is applied, and the hole in the center is the load.  As one lifts or pulls on the moving side, the "lever" pivots around the opposite side, moving the load (attached to the hole) half the distance, but with twice the force.

Destin, your section that included getting your Jeep stuck reminded me of a pair of tricks my father taught me about mechanical advantage. Neither use snatch blocks but both are useful if you have a length of chain or, in the case of being stuck a stout rope. Dad had taken a friend and I sledding (and wood hauling...), this is about 1966-7. He drove the old 4x4 out into a flat field that had 8" of powder snow and we set off to buck some birch and do some sledding. Upon our return, we discovered that under all 4 wheels of the truck there was a thick layer of solid ice. Even trying to ease the truck into motion wasn't happening, all 4 wheels were spinning as if the truck was on a hoist. Dad pulls out a length of 1" rope, tied it to the frame (separate lesson on a bowline knot) and instructed me to proceed with the other and to an anchor tree, put a wrap around it and pull it as tight as possible. He got in the truck and instructed my friend to push on the rope at the center of the line between truck & tree at right angles to the line. My buddy was able to push the rope 2-3 feet moving the truck just an inch or two. Dad applied the brakes, my buddy let up on the pressure & I took up the slack at the wrap at the tree. Rinse & repeat until we'd moved the truck a few feet where there was a little traction and we were free. This is the power of trigonometry! The force applied was my 50-60 lb. buddy on an icy surface to the rope, but the force applied (at first) to the truck was perhaps 30 lbs. / sin(~179.9999 degrees) or bunches (>100,000 lbs.)! As the angle drops from ~180, the force drops rapidly too, but a hundred foot rope keeps a high angle to this point for several feet. The other mech advantage trick was using a length of stout chain (35-40 lbs. 10') bolted to a stubborn axel in an old tractor needing removal. Using the mass and momentum of the chain to yank that axel in a couple of tries. I don't miss the cold and snow of Montana, but I do recall lessons well received... :)

The weight is purchased by the distance.... simple they knew that in like 5000 BC... it's the DISTANCE not tension dude... the SAME energy is being expended however by doubling the distance aka the amount of rope you need to LIFT the block you seem to make it easier.... however you still have to WIND up twice as much rope... the thing that pulleys do is PURCHASE WEIGHT with distance- that is the key to what is being done... nothing is free... the block & tackle was invented to reduce the distance that an actual horse, elephant human had to walk rotate wind up on a drum the LENGTH of rope that is purchasing the weight... so it's not about TENSION it's about LENGTH OF ROPE being added so that you reduce the particular energy at a point in time... over time & distance you still expend the SAME energy to lift the rope... the arrangement makes it easier so a human can wind 100 times the amount of rope quickly/easily rather than lift 1 yard of rope with all energy expended in a moment... this is also the reason an impulse force does such damage rather than static loads.... the load is applied in an instant... if you can slow down the applied loading & spread it out you can allow the force to move through rather than into the object... you need to study physics your empirical methods are failing to teach people the principle involved:
YOU PURCHASE the weight with LENGTH of rope... over time if you will... you get 8 lbs on the output through 2 lbs but you need to pull 4 times more rope to get it to same height! Aka do the same work! Also you will notice that the more pulleys you add the less it does the SAME WORK as before aka it is slowly becoming just a straight lever... so it isn't actually lifting any longer it is tilting more than lifting so the motion is no longer a VECTOR UP in the vertical.... thus you see by NOT actually winding up the rope & PAYING for the weight you purchased with DISTANCE you start losing the same work being done.... nothing is free! Also we never went to the moon & the pyramids were not built by the egyptians!

I did towing and recovery for a little while, and my most-used "non standard" equipment was definitely a snatch block. It opens up so many options. Not only letting you pull harder than your winch could normally do, but pulling from a direction you wouldn't be able to. There are some really neat tricks for a snatch block.


It always impressed me as being one of those tools whose usefulness was basically only limited by how clever you are... and how many you have on hand.

How do you turn 8,000 lbs of pulling force into 16,000? Snatch block!!


How do you pull a car that's stuck in park out of a parking space in a supermarket so you can turn it and load it onto a flat bed? Snatch block!!

How do you haul an 80,000 lb truck out of a ditch and back onto solid ground? Snatch blocks!!

Near the beginning I feel the focus on tension is misleading. Pulleys work like gears, ie by taking the work you put into moving your hands a distance d, and using that work to move a load only a distance 0.5d (or whatever ratio). It basically allows you to spread out your work so that your power output can be half as much for twice as long. I don't think tension really adds much to understanding this, particularly because the rope slides. It is not the same as having two people pull on fixed ropes.

Love the channel, the enthusiasm, the teaching.  In this case, I prefer this simple explanation - the reason that a SNATCHBLOCK works is because it significantly reduces the distance the weight is raised with each pull of the rope, thereby reducing the work required for each pull.  In physics terms, the easiest way to look at it is by using Work=Force*Distance.  If you cut the distance the weight moves in half, which a simple SNATCHBLOCK will do, then the work you must do is also cut in half.  Raising the weight then will, of course, take twice as long.  That is, twice as many pulls.  And twice as much rope must be pulled.

Fewer pulleys, not less pulleys. fewer is only to be used when discussing countable things, while less is used for singular mass nouns. For example, you can have fewer ingredients, dollars, people, or puppies, but less salt, money, honesty, or love. If you can count it, go for fewer. If you can't, opt for less. Smarter every day. :-)

Basic physics tells us that work is force times distance. Every time a pulley cuts the distances an object moves in half, the force to lift is hafted. If you take a pulley like the one you started your video with and tie the end of the rope to the small eyelet on top of the pulley and use a double pulley on top then run the rope up through one side of the double pulley back down through the bottom one and then back up to the top pulley. Now when you pull down the distance is one third so the force is one third.

Nice video and explanation . Be aware however, although these tools are very helpful in some situations a person can get themselves into really dangerous situations with heavy loads.  I witnessed a man lose one leg and practically destroy the other leg when a  choker holding a snatch block parted and the block and wire rope under tension hit him like a slingshot.  The only thing that saved his life was that it hit him knee height.  I'm not saying this is common, however accidents happen, never stand under a load, and never put your finger into a hole to check the alignment of parts.

A pulley system is basically a gear reduction system that spreads the load over time. If you pull twice the length of rope to move something a given distance than the load is halved, but you have to pull twice the distance. The explanation about single pulley redirecting the force and allowing you to pull with your weight is correct. A lot from that point on is wrong. The "redistribution of weight" between two lengths of rope is irrelevant. What really matters is redistribution of length : in the two-pulley system you pull two feet of rope for every foot of "useful work". This is simple leverage: you perform the same work (you raise the weight by one foot) over a longer distance (you pull two feet of rope), so you use half the force.

The second pulley in the car lifting scenario was used incorrectly . There was still 2:1 leverage and the extra pulley merely redirected the rope, which provides no weight-related advantage if you are pulling horizontally anyway. The correct solution would have been to attach the pulley where the rope previously ended, and pull the rope back through it, attaching the end of the rope to the hook on the car. This would give 3:1 leverage.

Was pondering how to lift 4x8 sheets of plywood to cover my upper story windows during hurricane evacuations. After way too much time, i thought "PULLEYS!" Never heard of a 'snatch block' before, but i put a hook over each window on the eave overhang. To pull the ply up, i hang one pulley on the hook, and a double snatch block (now that i know the name for it!) on the bottom attached to the plywood sheet. I pull the sheet up while standing on the ground with practically zero effort, then run up the ladder and swing it in the last little bit to attach it to the window. Easy-peasy. Don't have to worry about whether all the neighbors have already left, because this is now a one-man job! Just have to do it before the wind kicks up!

I have read a number of the posts here, and feel compelled to clarify a few things. The video is interesting, but the presenter does not explain the principle behind mechanical advantage machines, which is a shame, since he has obviously put so much effort into it.


Pulley systems, gearboxes and levers of all types are based on a single principle. "Work" in equals "work" out. This is using the frictionless model of course, to simplify the system. Work is defined as the product of force and distance, calculated as vectors. So assume the pull direction and the rope lie in the same straight line. To calculate the amount of "work" done, simply multiply the force by the distance traveled. In the case of a four rope pulley the distance traveled by the pull is four times the distance traveled by the load. It just happens to also give a number to the mechanical advantage of the system. 4:1.



One rotation on the input shaft of a transmission, gives one tenth a rotation of the output shaft. The MA is 10 to 1. For a lever, a given input force over 10 ft provides an output force over 1ft. The MA is 10:1. It is far more useful to see MA through the lens of "work" done as this principle applies to ALL systems, not just ropes and pulleys.


I leave you with chain blocks as a great example. You cannot see the internal workings of the machine but the gears inside reduce the number of rotations of the output shaft compared to the number of rotations of the input shaft. You can lift a 1 ton engine block with only 20 lbs on the pull chain. That is a MA of 100:1. But look at what is happening. You pull the chain almost ten feet to raise the load only about one inch. That is: work in = work out.


Hope that helps!

I thoroughly enjoyed this video!  I once made a 16x reduction set for my students (I'm a teacher).  It didn't have pulleys, but fishing line is easy to slip around nails.  We picked up bricks and even tried a chair, but we couldn't get the CG right to pick it up fully off the ground.  Back in '95, I worked in a Good Year conveyor belt factory.  They had a thing called the "festoon" which was probably at least 30x reduction.  When a roll of fabric would finish, they would put it in a press to start the next roll (a heated press that would cure a section of rubber to put the belt fabrics together).  During the stopped time, the hanging festoon would slowly rise from the floor with that same slow on one end and fast on the other motion.  After they would  join them, the roll would run a little quickly as the festoon made its way back down.  I NEVER got tired of watching this for the entire time I worked there!  I worked in the office, but the bathroom was across the factory floor.  I would stop and (admittedly) waste a lot of time watching this.  Keep up the good videos!!!!!

Honestly, I find your visual explanation to be a lot more confusing than "explaining it with words," and a lot less informative of the reasons WHY this works. That the rope moves less and less through additional pulleys isn't just an idle curiosity, it's THE reason why you're getting a mechanical advantage. A single movable pulley will - assuming parallel ropes - move half the distance of your pull, which is why it will apply twice the force. It has nothing to do with the ropes being "in tension" beyond that's what it takes for a pulley to work, or even the number of ropes. It has to do with how much work you're doing on your end of the rope vs how much work is being done on the load end.


Mechanical advantage is always the same concept whether you're using a lever, a pulley, a fluid piston, a gearbox or what have you. You're either trying to do more work with less force on one end in order to get less work with more force on the other, or vice versa. Different approaches might differ in the device used, but they all employ the same principles. The principles you skipped over all but entirely in favour of saying "snatch block" like you're trying to summon Beetlejuice. I get it, having physical props helps, but not if it comes at the expense of sidelining the actual physics which makes them work.

In physics, "Work" is defined as force times distance (or displacement). When you just lift the object alone, you need to use a lot of force. For every pulley mixed in, you can increase the distance traveled, and thus reduce the amount of force needed. And that's why a good winch has a REALLY long cable.

Good discussion and demonstrations.  An interesting byproduct of a change of direction pulley demonstrated at the beginning is the force relating to the anchor.   In the first demonstration,  change of direction pulley, when the rope is pulled down you have the force to raise the weight on one side of the pulley and the weight of the object on the other side of the pulley.   The anchor must support both (double the weight), as does the pulley and rope at the turn point of the pulley. He can place the force meter on the anchor point to demonstrate this important point.   This unique engineering point comes into play when a person is lifting incorrectly using their back muscles to lift which contract over the spine, muscle and connective tissue which acts as the anchor, pulley and rope in a change of direction mode.  Lifting incorrectly not only adds the upper body weight but increases force on the spine as well by this multiplying force factor.  It is similar to the force on the anchor of a fulcrum.

They're helpful for cave rescues. My first vertical cave trip (near Alabama, actually) I was getting tired climbing the last pitch and the guy up top was so excited to use his rescue pulleys I took him up on the offer. He made a 3 to one that had to be adjusted every few pulls with a secondary line that was attached to my harness (The rope wasn't long enough to double or triple over all the way down to where I was, so we had to work with that). Then I just moved my ascenders up as I was pulled to catch my progress each time he had to reset. It was really neat. I learned that day that haul systems are a lot of fun and if you have any bit of an excuse to assemble a system and use it, then heck yeah.

I was in a cave yesterday, in Georgia, and there was a room full of TONS of breakdown where we had to go through a 3D maze of boulders. There were bolts rigged around this gigantic mound of boulders and apparently if a cave rescue is required, a cave litter can't be twisted and bent enough to get through the 3D maze, so the cave rescuers will actually build a complex haul system using those bolts (with anchors removed most of the time so regular cavers don't get any ideas to unsafely rappel through the breakdown, since that's not what they're meant for, and if you're rappeling down to a part of the 3D maze, there's really no safe spot to get off rope unless you go to the very bottom, which goes no where) to haul the injured person in the litter up and over the breakdown. How it was described to me, I pictured two pulley haul systems, one on each side, with a traverse line in between to transfer them from one haul system to the other. Maybe even a third pulley system to more easily pull them horizontally along the traverse line, too.

Great video,  but I think this video fail to explain why the tension of the rope helped. If the video go further to explain that 2 sides of the rope is the same as 2 people carrying a 10kg object, that means each person is carrying 5kg. And pulling one side of the rope via pulley with 1 extra kg, is the same as one person adding 1kg of lift (6kg), so that one side is now higher than the other side, same in the pulley system since the snatch block will move the centre of gravity to the middle so lifting 6kg on one side will immediately even on both side, causing both sides got lifted but in a half distance comparing to just lifting one side in 2 people scenario.

I’m RIGHT with you Destin; I’ve been Fascinated with ‘Simple Machines’ since I was first introduced to them.
Think I finally recognized WHY ‘Simple Machines’ work:
It’s in the difference between ‘Work’ and ‘Power.’
Work is Force against resistance. POWER, though, is WORK over TIME.
So, machines allow us to divide work by MORE time, thus reducing POWER constraints!

How does the diameter of the pully effect it?

I usually describe it in terms of energy and W=F x d. With two pulleys you move the load 1/2 the distance you pull the line. So that the force at the load is 2 times the force on the puller but the puller pulls 2x the distance preserving energy. So in effect you can reduce the force delivered but you deliver it over a longer distance. Work/Energy is preserved.

This all is depending where the cable end is attached. If it cannot take the load, then you won't be able to apply the force you wanted to. Some conscripts learn it hard way when they use snatch blocks to pull 10-16 wheelers out of the mud but the tree is not big enough.

I think a better way of thinking about it is the amount of rope pulled through. Because you're pulling the rope running through the block, the 2 ropes either side are pulling half the distance they normally would if they were just attached to the weight. So you're gearing basically. You're changing one force over a certain distance to 2 over half the distance per side.

Simple terms it's like reduction gears just using pulleys & the gears are the rope. 1 pulley to lift object to 1 inch = 1 revolution, 2 x pulleys to lift object to 1 inch = 2 revolution and so on 4 pulleys to lift object to 1 inch = 4 revolution on the last pulley directly to the load or object. This is a reduction of 1:4 so when you add in weight factor say a 400 pond bag of rocks using 4 pulleys you have reduce weight force to lift the 400 pond bag of rocks to 50 ponds.  With this method I was able to lift & move a 1 tone object just with one hand using 12 block & tackle pulleys.

I think of pulleys like how I think about torque and gear ratios.
The reason it works is because it makes you move the same amount of mass a smaller distance with the same amount of force. Work equals force times distance. Because the distance has decreased, the amount of work you have to do also decreases, even if the force you're exerting doesn't change.

5:33 The first line will indeed move at the rate you are pulling, but the second line will move at a rate of (n-1)/n times that of the pull rate, or in this case 7/8 of the rate you are pulling.


Let the length of each line be L and v be the speed at which we are pulling. If we have n vertical lines in the system, then when the first line traverses a distance dS, the weight will move up a distance of dS/n and so each line will get shorter by this amount (this is assuming no friction). The (n-1)'th line will have to move at twice speed at which the weight is rising(2*v/n) since both the (n-1)'th line and the n'th line have gotten shorter by ds/n.


In general, the (n-k)'th line will move at a speed of v*(k+1)/n since each added line has to traverse an extra distance of dS/n. We can rewrite this using i=n-k => k=n-i, giving v*(n-i+1)/n. Thus for i=2 (aka. the 2nd line), the speed will be v*7/8 .

It's really important to understand that blocks themselves aren't the magic in the system, the magic actually comes from the "ceiling", from the "immovable" object which by not moving when the force is applied to it generates force equal to the one you apply to it. Blocks only allow you to use this amazing property of force logic in the ways that are actually useful, and apply them multiple times.

I would say the Archimedes pulling a ship is most likely a myth. Why? Because you need an "immovable" object to pull an object using blocks, and if you are going to generate just a little bit of force, the rest of the required force must come from somewhere

The snatch block is just halving your travel distance compared to length of rope pulled. Youre just gearing down. A normal pully, you pull a foot of rope, the object lifts a foot. WHen I was working as a professional mariner, we used the pulley concept every single day, multiple times a day. I used to tell new hires to think of blocks and tackles like using a lever; adding more pulleys was like adding length to the lever. Most seemed to get the concept pretty quickly.

As long as you're willing to trade effort for distance, there isn't much you can't move.

One thing that needs to be stressed is that the anchor point needs to be able to take the entire load: Not just the weight of the object, but the weight carried by each part of the tackle. Four ropes and a hundred-pound weight means a five-hundred pound strain.

I thought I'd drop you a note and let you know you helped me today.  I had to put up some shade cloth today over my back patio, and generally I would struggle to get the shade tight enough.  Today however after watching this video I thought I could adapt the pulley/snatch block scenario to this.  The rope is connected to the shade cloth, via an metal eyelet, the rope is then connected to the fence via a closed hook thing, (I'm so up the tech speak) Normally I would have just fed the rope thru the closed hook and tried to tie it off, whilst maintaining the tension, this time however I fed the rope the closed hook, back up through the shade cloths eyelet and then back through the fences closed hook.  The amount of strength required to get the correction tension on the shade cloth was almost nil and I could then maintain that tension easy and tie it off.  This is probably just general maintenance 101 but I missed that class so yeah happy days for me and thanks :D

I think one thing that's demonstrated here very well is the difference between power, and force. As humans we see ourselves as creating force, and ultimately we do to some degree. But we create force via power. So if we spread that force out over a greater period of time we can leverage power, to create more force. What we're seeing is the same process at play when you look at a gear reduction. Or when you compare a torquey pickup truck engine with a revvy sports car engine of the same horsepower. The difference is how that power is used to generate force, and over what period of time does that force exist.

I really hate to rain on the parade for the addition of the second block around 7:00 but since we're here for the sake of getting smarter every day: The way that second block was added to the system only caused a redirection; no increase in mechanical advantage.

For that, a better setup would have been to feed the other end through the second block and back to the car. That would have given you a 3:1 advantage.

That said, I don't want to detract from the two points being made: a). Blocks are awesome (in both senses), and b) practical experience will give you a much better intuition for the way they work than theory (though a mixture will probably get you the furthest).

An easy way to think of pulleys is sort of like a ramp. It takes less strength to push a ball up a ramp than to lift it over a wall. However, you have to move the ball farther to compensate, so the same energy is being used total. With a pulley, you have to pull for a larger displacement but with less force. This is why humans are genius. You'd think, well same total force, no point right? Wrong. Humans are creatures of endurance not power. If a human could unlock their full strength they could lift a car. The muscle strain and tearing would probably kill them though. But I can lift a car easy with a shitload of rope and not break a sweat. Because walking for ten minutes isn't as hard as running for one.

Hi Destin,
I think there may be a misconception in your video, and we've been talking about it at the fire station all morning. If you take the line off of your winch, take it to a single snatch block around a fixed object, and hook it back onto your winch-attached object, you don't have any mechanical advantage. Because there is no second change of direction, you only have a single change in direction, but you do have increased pulling power because there are two attachment points on the jeep. The winch itself isn't a pulley, so with one pulley you gain nothing but decreasing the load on the line, and increase the attachment points on the jeep. Is this correct? Thank you!
Andrew

Imagine just a single piece of rope of length "L" with one side fixed and the other side moving from +L to -L.  The distance of travel of the moving end is 2*L.  But the pulley just runs along the full length of the rope (so it travels "L").  Then, with conservation of energy, 2L * 1/2*force = L * force

This is one of your best videos, but you over use 'snatch-block', as opposed to sheaves and their actual assemblies in rigging (and no mention to ratings of rope or safe working loads). Snatch blocks are handy, but they are among the weaker elements in a pulley system.

That said, this was timely as I recently re-taught this subject to my daughter - a bad school experiment and an inept teacher ruining fun stuff like this for a whole class of kids. I'm ex-Navy so this was basic seamanship from 30 years ago.

If you really want to see cool rigging, look to WreckMaster and their towing training examples (vehicle recovery and righting), or construction where they suspend loads from two cranes, and swing that dual suspended load to a central area to place it - the forces and dynamics of those systems are awesome (dual pull, synchronized lift and lower to move loads sideways and keep it elevated, etc.).

You and Mike Rowe could do some awesome videos on this subject to get people re-motivated to the trades.

Gah! Where to start? You have to start with "work". Virtually everything will be easier to explain and explore if you do. W = force x distance. Pedaling a bike, shoveling gravel, or using pulleys. In using the pulley you have to pull the end of the rope twice as far as the mass is raised. Or 4 times or 8, etc. Pedagogically, as the teachers like to say, start with force and work. You will wind up using the work-energy theorem without even knowing it. I'm sure this video can spark interest, but I found it muddled and ill explained.

What really clicked for me was when I realized where the trade-off in the effort was. It's not magic. As you double the force lift you must also double the distance the rope travels. Need to lift a 100lb weight 10 Feet? With one pulley you can make it feel like a 50lb weight, but it needs to be pulled for 20ft. Two pulleys make it feel like 25lbs but 40ft of "distance". all the way down to making the load feeling like it only weighs 1lb but you must make that 1lb weight travel 100x the distance. This idea preserves the energy in the system. You're still expending the same amount of energy, but in a less intense way.

Your pully/hook at 0:06 is held upside down... it is a 3 to1...the rope working end is secured where your left hand/thumb is.... rope goes up, around another pully(double) and down around this single pully and back up to the ganged second pully and then free-standing end to pull down on... when set up it can be referred to as a Luff or Watch Tackle. ps love your channel...

The issue with adding all those lines is the significant force you’re placing on your anchors. If you put 8:1 MA on the cinder blocks, you’ll end up with like 8:1 on your anchors. All of a sudden, a 20 pound load is putting 160 pounds on your anchors.

You also significantly decrease any MA you have as soon as the ropes aren’t parallel. So in your truck example, your not pulling straight down, your lines are at like 45’s, so a big chunk of MA is lost and the load factor goes up on your anchors. Suddenly your MA becomes more of just a change in direction.

In your winch example, you’re putting 2x the force on that tree by adding the snatch block verse 1x if you just wrapped the winch around it. So your your load factor on that anchor doubled and for what? There’s no MA gained on the Jeep side because 1 goes in, 1 goes out but 2 gets placed on the tree. That would work if you wanted to pull the tree or something on that load side. The Jeep is your anchor point in this case, so nothing gained in pulling the Jeep.

At 8:47 he is Wrong saying that "putting the snatch block on the tree side and taking that hook and hook it back to the Jeep you would have TWICE THE PULLING FORCE". In fact it is the SAME THING as if he would have pulled directly to the tree. The winch pulled the WHOLE WEIGTH of the Jeep. He should have mounted ONE of the snatch blocks ON THE TREE and the OTHER ONE ON THE JEEP and finally tied up the end of the rope ON THE TREE, then and just then he would have had TWICE THE PULLING FORCE.

The SINGLE pulley system mounted to get the truck up onto the flat bed trailer when Jeff showed up and the DOUBLE pulley system they mounted after didn't do anything else but ONLY change the direction that the truck should pull (going backwards to the road).  The Curb weight of the truck is about 4,300 lb, therefore the Tension in the rope was aproximately HALF of the total weight. IF Destin would have had 3 pulleys (or snatch blocks) and mounted 2 of them ON the truck and the other one ON the trailer, the tension on the rope (in other words THE FORCE NEEEDED TO PULL THE TRUCK) would have been REDUCED to a QUARTER of the total weight.

Looking from the perspective of the anchor point weirded me out because that is something you should never ever ever do. I'm glad that you only risked your camera. Throwing the floor mats over the cable was also a really good idea. Some people also put their hood up so that, should the cable break, hard and heavy stuff is less likely to fly into your windshield.

Some people use those flat straps that look like seatbelt webbing. That is particularly dangerous if combined with something heavy like the steel hooks that the manufacturers insist on putting on the ends. Those straps store a whole lot of energy when under tension.

So, as a public service message, I would like to remind people to be extremely careful when combining large forces, hard and heavy equipment, and elastic ropes and straps. Be very, very mindful of which way things will fly if the strap breaks.

Just to clear up some possible confusion.
The pulleys that don’t move are simply redirecting force, they don’t add mechanical advantage. Only the pulleys that are moving add mechanical advantage. The second pulley added to the truck being put on the trailer only redirected, it did not add mechanical advantage. The Jeep is the exception to this rule because it’s a reverse situation.
The cable side that is pulled by the winch is moving twice as fast as the Jeep. 🤙
EDIT: and a better way to say it might be.....The pulling source is anchored to the load (Jeep), unusual and that’s why the formula doesn’t plug in right.

Another way to explain pulleys.... And im sorry if i use the 'x' incorrectly.  Is your using x energy to move x mass x distance over x time. To use less energy you need to change something else. By adding pulleys you're increasing the time for rope to go from point a to b. So overall you are using same amount of energy same distance same mass. Just lower amount of energy at any given moment over a longer period of time.

You did a great job of introducing very simple mechanical advantage (MA), however, there is so much more to it. For instance, when you added a second pulley to the rigging for the truck onto the trailer, you did not add any additional MA. You simply put in a change of direction (CoD) pulley. Awesome video! It would have been cool if you talked more about how the tension changes with the addition of pulleys. Like for example, adding a single pulley doubles the amount of tension on the rope, since you are pulling in one direction with force equal to the weight of the object, and the object is pulling in the opposite direction with the same weight. So lifting a 100lb object with a single pulley is actually putting 200lbs of stress on the rope

BUT (Its not my field so I might be wrong, it would be great if you can correct me in case I am)


When you pulled the truck, with 1 snatch block you ~optimized the force that can be generated (~x2), BUT when you added the second snatch block, you basically haven't changed anything! You generated the same force with double the gear, as the tension of the rope is still the force generated by the pulling truck and the force on your truck is still ~x2.
You could generate x3. (explanation below).


I was thinking about it a while ago, and I've found a way to improve the force generated by the system (probably a known way, but it wasn't to me), so you may consider it next time you need to use snatch blocks.


Consider every snatch block to have one input (force applied on rope= F) and 2 outputs (force at the top = 2*F and force at the other end of the rope = F ).
You could connect the end of the rope to the object, so you get F on the object.
Now you can connect the top of the snatch block to a rope and feed it as an input to another snatch block (like Archimedes).
You can keep doing it until you are out of snatch blocks, and connect the top of the last snatch block to a strong plan.
At the end, you get {F*sum(2^0,2^1,2^2,2^number of snatch blocks-1)}. I think that this solution is optimal for n>=2 snatch blocks.
This is better, because Archimedes solution (as you presented) generates only 2^(number of snatch blocks-1).


NOTE:
-Considering the truck problem, you shouldn't be worried about the force in the connection of the last snatch block because you could split it between the 2 connections you have to the flat bed trailer.


If the explanation isn't clear, let me know, and I'll send you a diagram with the calculations. If you know of an even better solution, please let me know.


**Keep uploading great videos!!!**

****Edit****
I am partialy wrong.
You really didn't improve force with the second snatch block, and by using Archimedes methos you could pull with ×4.
My solution is optimal only under some constrains (when you can't pull from the better direction, a problem you didn't have with the truck).
Your pulling it twice as far. It's simple gearing or leverage.

One important side note is the potential danger when using pulleys. Most people look at the carrying capacity of the beam they are tied to and assume that is the max they can lift. They forget that they can only pull half that weight if they are pulling from below with a pulley. There is the force of your load pulling down and the force you are exerting on the rope (both on the downward direction). Basically you had the equivalent of 4 cinder blocks on top of that ladder in the video not 2.  same goes holds true when the kind samaritan added the snatch block to the trailer. The force on steel bar on the trailer doubled.

Been sailing since I was a kid, working with pullies they whole time, for some reason I can know exactly how they work but the way you explain it with tension and so forth confuses me.

My brain thinks of it like this: It's the rope version of a ramp. The way a ramp let's you spread out work over distance, so does a block and tackle system. You make the job easier by making it longer. You reduce the speed at which you pull an object to increase the ease of moving it. It's just a trade off, nothing magical. If you can understand why pushing a block up a ramp is easier than lifting it straight up, you can understand why a block and tackle is so advantageous.

I'm sure that I'm not the first one to point this out, but those first two items you held up, are called blocks, not pulleys. A block will contain one or more sheaves, (the round spinny part) and has one or two sides to support the shaft or pin. A block changes the direction of pull of a rope, line, or cable.
A pulley is a round disk of sorts, with one or more grooves, that's mounted on a shaft and either is driven by the shaft, or drives the shaft, like those spinny things that your fan belt rides on in your vehicle. Pulleys are often used on electric motors, or gasoline engines to drive rubber V-belts, flat leather belts, or multi-groove belts. Pulleys can also be flat pulleys, with or without a crown. A bandsaw blade rides on 2 to 4 pulleys, called wheels. One is driving, the others are driven.
And yes, I'm aware that most people call anything that looks like a pulley, a pulley, but that doesn't make it a pulley. That's the reason they aren't called "snatch pulleys".

I used to do volunteer cliff rescue in Australia. A big part of the job involved abseiling and building these pully rigs to rescue people trapped in various places. We were trained in not just the use of the pullys but also in the physics involved. Theres a whole lot of other factors involved which can have different effects. Like the different loads placed on individual items of equipment depending how many pullys are involved, the angle that the rope leaves the pully effects the load on your anchor point, the difference between a mechanical advantage and a re-direction and ghe effect of friction force on different lengths of rope. I reccomend checking out some videos about cliff rescue etc to get a better idea. But great video Mate!!!

In nautical terms they are called blocks, not pulleys.  Block and tackle refers to the blocks and lines that are reeved through them and even the shackles used to attach the system to a rigid structure.  If you look at the parts of a block, the "pulley" portion is called a sheave.  So, a "block and tackle" though typically two double sheave blocks is merely a common 3:1 pre rig found on ships and may really be any combination of blocks and lines.

Good explanation. Another way to think about it: attach a pulley to the weight, pass a rope through the pulley and lift on both ends of the rope by yourself. You're lifting the entire weight, X. Now hand one end of the rope to a friend and you both lift. Clearly your friend is helping left 1/2 the weight and you're lifting the other end. Now replace your friend with an eyebolt attached to the ceiling and tie their end of the rope to the bolt. So now the bolt is taking 1/2 the weight instead of your friend and you're still taking the other 1/2. For some reason, this explanation clicked with me the first time I heard it.

Notice that the ratio is equal to the number of sheaves in use. Notice too that when you add sheaves to the system you also increase the amount of rope that needs to be pulled through to move the object being moved. One sheave is a 1:1 ratio, pulling the rope 10 feet moves the object 10 feet. Eight sheaves is an 8:1 ratio, pulling the rope 80 feet moves the object 10 feet but only requires 1/8 the effort over 8 times the time.

Great video, however I feel like you missed a great opportunity to show the pulley example that always stumped me as a child. That being a single pulley attached to the load, but with both ends of the rope suspended in the air. I.E. the load is below you and you are pulling on one end of the rope while standing on a platform that the other end of the rope is affixed to. This scenario is challenging for many students, because it looks like the pulley is just redirecting the force and not multiplying it. The similarity with having a single pulley suspended in the air which redirects the downward pulling force to an upward force (the simplest use of a pulley) on the load often confuses people.

A couple of those are not useful applications of a snatch block. Pulling the F150 onto the trailer, of course it's slow. You already had mechanical advantage from the handles on the ratchet straps. An F150 is not that heavy to require more.


As for the Jeep. That is a silly way to hook up winch cable(s) unless the vehicle is absolutely buried. If you actually need a snatch block for that amount of "stuck" then you frankly bought too small of a winch. The true advantage of a snatch block with a winch is allowing a smaller vehicle to pull a larger heavier one with the assistance of a fixed object like the tree you incorrectly placed the snatch block on or another small vehicle. The snatch block should go on the stuck vehicle and only when one is required.

Some he didn't mention, and should have stressed more, was pay attention the the strength of your anchor points. You could get yourself in a bind real fast when you start doubling, quadrupling forces and an anchor point gives way. Just out of high school my first near miss in the work world was seeing 10 metric tonnes (22,000 lb.) snatch blocks fall 18m (59 ft.) because the anchor on the wench pulled free.
For the rig hands: The boys had just finish tying back the bridle line and a green driller figured he was going to be a hero by bring the block to the rig floor so we could put on the bails. During rig up we had only strung enough line to have 13 raps on the drum to lift the derrick. As the green driller lowered the blocks the the line on the drum pulled free with only 2 or 3 raps on the drum. Moral of the story know how many raps you need on the drum at pick up point.

When it comes with block and tackle mechanical advantage can also be increased by the direction you're pulling, if you're taking the examples in his video where he was pulling on the standing or non moving block that's considered pulling to disadvantage, in that case you just count the lines to find the mechanical advantage but if you turn it around and pull from the moving block it's considered pulling to advantage and you also count the input line with the mechanical advantage giving and extra plus one.

So that thing I do to pull my fence to the post.


For reference I have had to take apart my chain link fence a few times, and I got sick of having to pull it forward get the bolt in because it was a lot of work stretching the fence back to the post. So I grabbed some rope, tied it to the post, threaded it through the links going up, pulled tight, thread it through going down and pulled it tight. Held my fence in place so I could bolt it back to the post.


Just make sure that if you use this method to skip the links where the bolts go, else the rope will be in your way.

Lifting using your body weight can make things easier, but to do heavy lifting you actually have to do the opposite.
For example, if I were to hang from a rope, the most I could lift (with no friction) is my body weight, approximately 115kg.
If I were to stand directly over the rope and pull up I can lift about 450kg. Plus my body weight.
Also, adding the number of ropes is over simplifying the mechanical advantage. Each of the ropes must share the work load and be on the running end or they do not add to advantage.
What I mean is, you have four strands going through the cinder blocks to the snatch block. Mechanical advantage is 1:1.


A tip, your Jeep wasn't really stuck and required little force to pull it. If you had pulled hard you may have knocked over those little trees.
What you can do there is use a snatch block, put a strap anchored to two trees near the base, a snatch block in the middle for a self balancing anchor point to distribute the load equally between the two trees. You can do it also with more threes but it gets more complicated. No mechanical advantage for your pull, but divides force and prevents damage to the trees.

This is a play on ratios. The distance the rope travels over the distance the pulley(s) travel. A ten speed bicycle operates the same way with the chain speed to driven tire ratio. Multiplied force on the target object is the goal. 90 degree interface between rope and pulley creates optimal advantage. Side note: Your kids are strong enough to never need mechanical advantage!

There is actually something called "The Golden Rule of Mechanics" that looks into it: "Whatever you save in power you make up in displacement" - (Galileo Galilei in 1594).

In other words, its not a free trade. And while in most cases you will cladly pull longer on ropes to save force, there are also cases where you do the opposite or are limited in the max. displacemnet => even pulleys arent perfect...

I worked out how pulleys worked when pulling vinyl flooring off the floor (I'm a floor layer) and I noticed that when I grabbed one end of the vinyl and started pulling I essentially walked backwards twice as far as the amount that I was actually pulling off the floor. Bit of mental gymnastics later and I came to the realisation that pulleys are basically trading force for distance. You need twice as much rope and need to pull twice as far but its half as hard. I know it's not exactly a typical way to work it out but it's what worked for me.

Also please don't stand that close to a winch cable when winching out a car. If one of about 5 things break the tension can cut your head off. It's a cool shot but people literally die by standing too close to recoveries gone wrong.

Dont forget that its not only twice the pulling force from the pulley system on that jeep, but the winch has more pulling force because you let out more rope. A winch has more force with an empty drum than it does with a full drum because the torque of the motor is constant, but the diameter of the drum changes - bigger drum puts the force further out from the axis of the drum, lowering its effective torque. Smaller drum places the rope closer to the axis for more effective torque.

Hey Destin, be careful man. As an oil rig worker snatch blocks are a way of life, along with sticky situations out 4x4ing. One thing that concerned me a bit is how close you stand to the rigging when its under tension. I've personally seen equipment fail and it can get dangerous really fast. Here's a few quick safety tips to live by when pulling/winching a vehicle out. Keep yourself out of the line of fire,  if something breaks its trajectory will be inline with the cable or rope. Always stay twice the length of your longest line away from the work (unless absolutely necessary). If you have to pull on or with the front of a vehicle the hood should be put up. A 5 pound snatch block will easily come right through your windshield however not so much the hood. And inspect your equipment before you use it. Its also a good idea to know the ratings of your equipment, identify the weak link and place it strategically in the system so that if it does fail it will cause the least damage and/or person injury. Play safe and happy mudding.

Destin: Most of your viewers do something everyday that operates very similar to the block and tackle rope speed you show at ~5:45. I recognize that motion from pulling my shoelaces tight each morning.


The place where the laces crosses sides nearest your toes often kinks and acts as a sort of anchor, with the eyelets acting as the pulleys, though admittedly the analogy is not exact. But as you pull on the lace, it moves at a different speed each time it crosses sides, from fastest near the ankle to slowest near the toe. And the force exerted is similar, from tightest near the toe to loosest near the ankle.

conservation of energy:  force * distance = energy input to the system.  small force for a long distance must equal a large force * small distance.  this is how levers, hydraulics, pulleys, inclined planes, etc. all work.

You forgot one of the most amazing advantages of the pulley which is not even a mechanical one. A pulley gives you the ability to reach above your arms. A single man can lift something 300ft over his own head using a single rope and a single pulley.

It's all about splitting the weight of the object.  When an object is lifted with one snatch block, half the object's weight is being pulled by you and the other half is supported/held by its anchor point where the rope is tied off.  Think of a couch as being a snatch block.  Much easier to move when you have someone help lift on the other side.  Half the total weight/force needed per person.

My visceral reaction to pulleys is I still have to pull just as hard because it is a single rope in my hands. The fact that the force is spread over many rope segments seems almost irrelevant because I'm holding a single rope. To make sense of this I shift my thinking and pretend I'm pulling on a lever. As the lever gets longer (more rope segments) I use less force even though I am still pulling on one part of the lever. Similar to the pulleys, a long lever requires I pull over a longer distance to make the load move. Not sure this is a good analogy but it works for me.

Each pass of the rope is pulling with the same force as we are but only one end can move. The more passes of rope the more rope we need to pull to make up for it. Trading distance for force. We are making one larger so the other can be smaller. This balances out the work equation (work = distance * force). Less force, more distance, same work.

You neglected to touch on another reason more parts of line are used: it allows you to lift loads with smaller lines that couldn't individually handle the load. More parts of line (POL) allow more weight to be lifted with the same rope/line. It wouldn't be functional to lift tons of weight with huge diameter line, more parts of line allow smaller, more flexible line to be used. This works in conjunction with the pulley systems to allow smaller winch motors. This would make an excellent part two video.

How I always understood it since I saw it on Mr. Wizard's World as a kid is that pulleys apply the rule that work is force x distance. A pulley allows you to decrease force you pull on the rope at cost of increasing distance the end of the rope you pull has to travel. In a way, pulleys are the pull version to hydrolic's push version applying the idea of pressure (force over area).

What I like in this video, though it only mentions in briefly, is that tension is not universal along the width of the rope. The modified pulley system of Archimedes at the end demonstrates that rope you pull on can be thin, but each layer will need thicker rope as the tension will get exponentially stronger, if I understand it correctly.

It doesn’t always impress people. I was going to this gym and there was a bicep curl machine that ran a cord from one handle down to a pulley attached to the weight plates and over to the handle of the other arm. Like this: ^\__?__/^

Some people would claim that if you curled one arm at a time you would lift whole weight of the plates with one arm as opposed to spreading the weight across both arms. I insisted and showed diagrams that even if you don’t use both arms at once each arm still pulls (approx.) half the weight of the plates.

Shiv-blocks. The rope wheel is the shiv and it is mounted in a block (block of wood in the old days), snatch block is as demonstrated a special block that can snatch a line in the middle. A shiv is not strictly necessary in a block but it does greatly reduce friction making the system more efficient, also a shiv can be hard mounted to a structure without a block, often seen at the top of a mast for the halyard.
Should be noted the 8:1 tackle using fewer shivs has the disadvantage of a very limited range of motion as compared to the first 8:1 tackle. Fine for simply adding a bit of tension to something but less useful for general movement.

Love your videos I watch em all! But I had to take a moment to correct you on this video. I am a climbing arborist by day so I work with lots of rope pulleys blocks and connectors. In this video you printed "double sheaves pulley's" and called them a block and tackle. They are simply called double sheaves pulley's. A block and tackle is when you have a system setup with rope and two or more double sheaves pulley's rigged together. Also you speak about Ziplining and refer to the pulley used as "basically a snatch block" Ziplining pulleys are just pulleys with a closed Becket instead of an open Becket. And the reason behind that is redundancy. In an open Becket if the axle for the sheave fails the rider would fall. With a closed Becket pulley there is additional safety as the axle could fail and the Becket would still hold the rider on the line ;)

I work in construction and on our 275T crawler crane (mobile crane on tracks) uses a 6 - 1 mechanical advantage block and tackle. As you demonstrated here with your 8 - 1, you saw a noticeably slower rate at which the object got hoisted. This is why a lot of industry professionals call these lifting types on cranes the "old man" because they're slower and also why most crawler cranes come with an auxiliary "whip" line for picking lighter loads more efficiently (mainly faster) which use a single cable around 1 "pulley" at the end of the main boom or jib extension.

One thing I'm surprised you never mentioned is a drawback with complex pulley systems, friction. Basically, the more complex system you have with more contact points on the pulleys, the less advantage you get due to added friction. So to get extra advantage you would use a compounding system similar to the one shown at 9:48. One of my favorite examples of this is on a sailboat called the laser. The modern set-up has a 15:1 advantage on a control line called the boom vang, but it has a 3:1 times a 5:1 to reduce friction.

At first I was getting confused about how this was working, because you basically multiply torque over a rotating surface without the need of changing any ratios of the rotating parts (like you would with the gears in a transmission). At 3:36, Destin was describing how there are 2 arrows showing an upward force. That only confused me further because there were also 2 arrows pointing down, which to me means those forces cancel out. But then I later realized there's an easier way to interpret the situation:
For each pulley you include, you are halving the amount of force necessary to lift the object, because the pulley splits the weight of the load into on each side of it. In other words, since each pulley is mounted to a fixed location, it effectively is distributing the load across the rope to each point it is mounted to. So if you were to measure how much force is applied to each mounting point (including the hand pulling the rope), they should all read the same number, and should collectively add up to the object's actual weight.

I like this way of explaining it. I understand that Work=Force*Distance, but that's not something everyone understands innately. I was going to explain compound pulley systems, but I'm glad to see you beat me to it, because those are REALLY hard to explain to people.

the gist of this, and the things you can do:
>if a pulley is anchored to immovable surface, it does no work of it's own, it just redirects any rope/line going through it.(the pulley at the top of the ladder)
>If it's anchored to a movable load, then it moves half as far with twice the force for the same amount of rope (work is conserved). add another pulley to this block? 1/4 the distance, 4x the force, same work. 3 pulleys on the block? 1/6 of the distance, 6x the force.
>if the pulley's rope is attached to the block of another pulley (a compound system), the same applies, but this time it doubles the force *of that pulley*, not the person pulling the rope. each additional pulley doubles the force of the pulley before it. This adds up quick
>you can anchor the 'free' end of the rope to the pulley block itself (that's why there are two eyelits on that block and tackle), this is also what cranes do since they don't want to anchor the fixed end of the line far from the load. this is also useful becase.....
>*Nothing stopping you from combining both systems.* a compound system made of three single pulleys (we don't count the fixed one) is 2x2x2, or 8. Double the number of pulleys on each block and it's 4x4x4, or *64*. To do the latter, instead of connecting the rope of each pulley directly to the one above, you hook a static pulley to the bottom eyelit. then wrap the line through and tie it off on the top eyelit of the block below. This is done on old Tall Ships. 6 men walking on the capstain can lift several tons of yardarm this way. imagine 4-5 blocks in a compound arrangement, each with 2-3 pulleys.
>You can attach snatch-blocks to each other to emulate block and tackle.
>The most crazy thing I've seen people do with pulleys involved chaning two three-pulley snatchblocks to two trees, setting up a four block compound system with the line coming out near the middle of the two. They hooked it to an old pickup and pulled the trees together hard enough that they came out of the ground and fell over. All because someone couldn't be bothered to get a new chainsaw chain. I miss the South sometimes.

A way that I've always thought about the mechanical advantage effect is basically the same as levers. With each added pulley you get extra force, but have to pull extra rope. You get the same trade off with levers. If you double the length of one side of a lever, you can apply extra force to the other, but have to move it further as well.

I've always thought of snatch blocks as a circular distribution of levers. You can think of it like a lever that runs from the 3 o'clock to 9 o'clock position of the pulley with the load bearing point right at the virtual center of the pulley. Make a whole series of those levers in a radial group and voila!  you have a "SNATCHBLOCK!".

Fundamentally, the pulley system works exactly the same way as the lever: if you set up your system so that you are pushing/pulling n times as far, you have an n-to-one mechanical advantage and can use 1/n the amount of force, for n times as long. If it weren't for inefficiencies in your system due to stuff like friction, the amount of work you do would be exactly the same, because work = force times distance. So if you're willing to pull the rope or push the lever for a long distance over the course of time, you can lift an aircraft carrier (or the world, if you have a place to stand, and strong enough materials to make the rope/lever out of). This is theoretically fourth-grade physics, but most students (and I think most teachers for that matter) zone out ("boring") and don't pay enough attention to actually understand what is going on. They just memorize enough formulae and/or facts to pass the test and then move on with their lives.

Great video! Loved it! But there are 2 small mistakes:

1) 0:45 When you pick up a block, you just need to lift the weight of the block. The normal force provided by the ground on your feet is the weight of the block + the weight of you (assuming you lift it slowly).

2) 5:24 that's not the reason why that side of the block moves up less quickly. If the bearings for each of your pulleys were completely frictionless you would notice the bottom block move unifromly upwards. This is because the influence of friction creates a counter torque which increases the tension in the rope on the left, and reduces the tension in the rope on the right.

Ready for math? Anchoring on the weight to be pulled will always give an odd ratio mechanical advantage ( 1:1, 3:1, 5:1 etc), while anchoring off of the load will give an even ratio (2:1, 4:1, 6:1 etc)...

The trade off... whatever ratio you have set up, you have to pull that much extra rope through. That is, on your 8:1 setup, if you wanted to move your load 1 meter, you’d have to pull 8 meters of rope through your system. So make sure you have enough rope length 😋

Here's the short and sweet of pulleys: You trade the rope pull length for force.  If you double the length of rope pull, you double the force.  5 times the rope pull, 5 times the force.  If you pull the rope the same distance the object moves, you've only redirected the force, not increased it.  If you increase the length of pull, you increase the force.

The way I have always though about it is, the mechanical advantage in a block and tackle comes from the multiplication of force that manifests itself in the fact you have to move the end rope some multiple of the thing you are pulling.  For example, to get 8 times the force in a block and tackle, you need to "move" the end of the rope 8 times as far. The exact same way a 2 foot long wrench would exert twice the force of a 1 foot long wrench but you have to move the "end" of the wrench twice as far.  Simple mechanical advantage. [fulcrum short story]  Once upon a time way out in the country a woman in a mobile home had a wheel chair ramp once belonging to a school out building delivered by five BIG guy's for free . It was slid off of a long trailer to her back door (via rollers) Once it was dropped there was no moving it by these guys [it] just weighed way too much so they wished her luck and left . It was inches away from the threshold and not high enough  while sitting on grass and soft dirt.

Many tried and failed . Then I arrived two days later , and by myself created a fulcrum from objects nearby . i.e. one railroad tie cut in half , one 4x4 twenty feet long , some small blocks , and a cinder block . With just 6" of the end of the 4x4 underneath the heaviest part of the ramp I placed some blocks under the 4x4 and raised the far end of the 20' length of 4x4 about 4' in the air and wedged the cinder block upright under it .

I went back to the end sticking underneath this ramp and stacked enough little blocks on top of my 4x4 to sit tight under the platform of the ramp . The two pieces of railroad tie I positioned near each corner and went back to the far end . I just removed the cinder block and with very little effort or body weight I pushed the raised end to the ground and placed the cinder block on top to hold it there   while I slid the ties under each corner .

The ramp was high enough , all I had to do now was give it a slight shove up against the threshold and the fulcrum , the small blocks and the long board teeterd just enough for it to slump down onto the ties in perfect position . Nobody saw how I had done it so I was a magician for a day . THE END

there's one thing this video doesn't make clear enough to make the understanding of how pulleys work "click" in my mind.

at 3:12 you do explain this, however the language you use doesn't make it click, here's is how I would explain how pulleys give mechanical advantage:

a single pulley does not reduce the force required, but rather creates a change of direction, while it might be easier for a person to lift something cause they're using their own weight in their favour, it doesn't change the fact that say a fixed winch would not gain any advantage from using a single pulley (this is important for later)

now here's the important bit, when there's a force on a single rope, that rope would be supporting the entire force. If the force hung on two equally thought ropes, the force would be split by those two ropes, likewise for even more ropes. The pulleys allow you to use a single rope as multiple ropes, while also automatically distributing the force onto all the ropes equally. therefore the amount of force that gets transfered to you, is equal to the force divided by the number of ropes attached to that force. now for the final pulley that only cause a change of direction, since the rope connected to it is bearing the force divided by the number of ropes connected to the same force, by having this pulley change direction, you only feel as much force as that rope is feeling.

In order to lift blocks on the end of a pulley system like that, then you need to shorten all of the ropes meaning that each time the rope goes up and down it has to travel twice as far. Awesome video Destin but your explanation was a little lacking. Here is a simplified version. The upper of stationary pulleys simply redirect motion. The lower or moving pulleys divide the effective motion in half starting with the first or fast line pulley, effectively doubling the pulling force with each pulley ending at the dead line. Since each moving pulley divides the range of motion in half, with respect to the previous pulley, the leverage is doubled with respect to the previous pulley. So a four pulley setup (four stationary and four moving) multiplies sixteen times while an eight pulley multiplies two hundred and fifty six times.
The fascinating thing is, each line is only carrying the amount you are pulling on your end.

Great job with the explanation. Wonderful video. Keep up the good work. Having said that, I want to make 2 points:-
1. The reason the rope closer to the part being pulled move more than the rope further away is friction. This is also the reason why for a 3d printed snatch block the mechanical advantage won't be 2. Friction is a <enter favourite bad word>. Using the simple model for friction you can show that with every wrap around a pulley, the tension grows exponentially.
2. I doubt the story about archimedese raising a ship with pulleys is true. This is because the more pulleys you youse more the friction. This is due to the exponential increment in the tension with each pulley turn.

I wanted to add though something i think its important about snatch blocks and leverage, that wasn´t explicetedly said in the video.


Even though snatch blocks are awesome by multiplying the force you put in, the amount of work (work = force x distance) you have to do is still the same. Without snatch block, for example, you would have to do W1 = 5F x 2D and with snatch block you would have to do W2 = F x 10D. In other words, no matter the amount of snatch blocks, the total amount of energy you have to put in is the same, only the forces and distances will be different, which, in the cases shown in the video, a big distance is irrelevant since you only care about your force available.


Anyway, just wanted to point that out cause, as they say, there are no free lunches in the universe lol

That length of rope or cable between the fixed point and the pulley bears a load that you no longer do, once the item is lifted a given amount. You no longer have to supply force to maintain that distance lifted, which is why when you hand over hand pull things up with a pulley, you don't find it as hard to hold the item where you've lifted it up to. The compound pulley systems are effectively a gearing system, without cogs.

Work=Force x Distance. one pully doubles the distance required to be input, but halves the force required. ultimately, the same amount of work is input and output, its just changing which side of the equation you want to invest your effort in. distance or force. all mechanical advantage works like this. pullies, levers and fulcrums, hydraulics, etc. if you have to lift 500kg 1 meter off the ground, its more manageable to pull 10 meters of rope with "50kg" of force so to speak. more accuratly, 490 newtons of force

Actually unfortunately through the law of conservation you are not putting less energy by using the pulleys! Probably a little bit more actually because of friction. The law of conservation says you must always put in as much energy as you get out. So for you to raise the blocks a meter off the ground with pulleys and reduce the force you're using by a quarter, you still have to do the same amount of work. It's just that you have to pull the end of the rope four times further to make each of the four supporting sections of rope rise by the same amount.

I liked this video but it didn't teach why pulleys work.

I've had to find a website that could explain it correctly. You explained how to make a pulley system, and how the mechanical advantage can be calculated. But why is interesting.

There's nothing magical about pulleys.
If you lift something with a rope, you're having to create tension in the rope until the force transmitted by the rope equals the force gravity exerts on the mass and then breaks that balance and the thing moves up, let's say one meter.
You generated a certain amount of force to get it one meter higher, you pulled one meter of rope.
The total amount of energy exerted to realize this operation is 1. (just setting it for reference).

Taking the same weight, you introduce a pulley system that has a mechanical advantage of 4. You're still creating tension in the rope, but four times less, until you break the balance and the thing starts moving up. But with this system you have to pull 4 meter of ropes to get it moving up 1 meter.
You generated four times less force but pulled four times as much rope. The total amount of energy exerted to realize this operation is still 1.

So, pulleys work by reducing the amount of force you have to generate, by increasing the length you have to pull.
For humans, it's easier to pull four times less four times further, but that doesn't require less force, and thus the law on the conservation of energy is not broken.
You don't multiply the force generated, you displaced the effort over longer. Sort of like payment plan with no interest, if that makes sense.

Adding the second snatch block when pulling the vehicle onto the trailer only redirected the force (which was, I hope, your goal), it added no further mechanical advantage (unless you were to pull while standing on the vehicle being loaded). To add more mechanical advantage run the rope from the vehicle where it is tied off through a block attached to the trailer, through the second block attached to the vehicle, and the finally to the tow vehicle.

Please note: you don't get a free ride by ganging pulleys. In the block and tackle, T in each member leg is roughly equal. In your ganged pully example, each leg of the tension bearing member must bear all tension applied by the previous member: In other words the tension in the last rope is much higher than the tension on the first rope.
Your efficiency gain comes from having a material with can bear the tension much greater than the load, which may or may not be optimal compared to having an extra pulley.

I'm a tow truck driver and this might be one of my new favorite videos. Especially since I just went out and did a winch out requiring 4 separate lines, 5 snatch blocks and 2 trucks. If you want some real good, real world experience, find a tow truck guy that has been around for a while and you'll learn some tricks you never would've thought of.

Two points of clarification:
1.) The extra snatch block for pulling the truck onto the trailer (7:25) just redirects the pulling force, it does not add any mechanical advantage. To gain mechanical advantage (3:1 instead of 2:1), it could have been configured with the second snatch block on our left and attach the end of the cable back to the truck.
2.) The Archimedes configuration of fewer pullies (9:35) has different forces in each cable. Therefore, to pull the warship, one of the cables needed to have the strength of 1/2 the force on the warship. The earlier configuration with more pullies has the same cable tensile force throughout, so it could be accomplished with a smaller cable.

Great presentation - just want to add one safety warning: just because you're pulling with less force, doesn't mean you should neglect the stability of the support (i.e., the ceiling, tree etc.). The support is the thing that provides more and more of the force as you increase the number of pulleys... In fact, the magic of pulleys is that you share the pulling force with the support. This is easy to overlook because the support doesn't move so it doesn't do any of the mechanical work... but it's essential nonetheless.

How pulleys give mechanical advantage though? The intuitive explanation i remember is something like:
If you have a block with 1kg suspended by a rope attached to a ceiling, the rope is under tension of 1kg and the ceiling is supporting 1kg. If you have 2 ropes attached to the ceiling they would both be under tension of 0,5kg and the ceiling supporting 1kg. If you hold one of the ropes and let the ceiling support the other one you would only need to support 0,5kg. To lift something with 1kg you would need more than 1kg of force. A pulley let you use a single rope as two and without losing the tension that's supporting the block, thus, you only need >0,5kg of force to lift an 1kg object. But, the ceiling isn't moving, so the rope you are holding needs to move double the distance than the block you are lifting.

I love pulleys! I always make time to explain them a bit more in depth in my mechanics courses. It's such an easy way to get students interested, and it's such cool practical knowledge.


I also find them theoretically very pleasing. What you're doing when combining pulleys is exerting a constant force in a certain direction that gets amplified because you help the wall / ceiling / tree pull with you. This is the simplest way to explain work / energy that I know of. Because of the constant force that's parallel to the displacement, the formula to calculate the work you're doing with your force simplifies to W = F . x. No matter how you're arranding the pulleys, when you want to lift a block you need to do a set amount of work. Therefore, you're always trading force for distance in equal proportions.


For many students these lecures are such a clarifying moment when it comes to work and energy, which are kind of abstract concepts.

I don't like your explanation to be honest. Saying both lines are at the same tension doesn't do it for me.
The way i see it is that twice the distance you pull on the rope is going to be half the distance on the load. Intuition therefore tells me you will have double the force.
The same way gears work, if you have a 2:1 gear ratio, the input gear will have to make two revolutions for the output gear to make one. Meaning you get double the torque for half the speed.

Your explanation might work better for other people though.
And to finish it off, it's the same as a seesaw where you place the fulcrum at 1/3 the length of the lever. Twice the movement on the long end of the lever will give you half the movement on the other end. But of course twice the power.

Hmm, let's see if i can think of another example... Well yes kinda, if you are to walk up some stairs and you are given two options. One set of stairs are at a 45 degree angle and the other is at 22.5 degrees.
The steeper stairs will take you to the top much faster but you will have to exert much more of your own torque to get up those 45 degree stairs.
The stairs at 22.5 degrees will take you more than twice as long to get to the top but you won't really be using much effort getting up those stairs, rather stamina.


Now, imagine you are carrying a washing machine with a buddy, which stairs would you prefer?

So as a student of practical engineering I'm pretty sure I can try and explain this with some more math for those interested, I know I was hoping for Dustin to explain some math there.
So for starters, a Force applied on an object following a circular instead of a straight one is called a Moment. A Moment is marked by the letter M, the definition of a moment is a Force multiplied by an Arm.
Or M=F*L
F is the force applied to the object, like a man pulling a rope.
L is the Arm which is the distance from the centre of the point around which the force is applied to the point where the force is applied.
So we can see that the longer the distance from us to the point where we want the force to work at the bigger the moment.
In our case the farther away we are from the centre of the pully the bigger the moment we can apply while keeping the force the same.
By adding pullies we can increase our force which each one we add by getting the force it applies farther from a new centre (the added pully). If we connect them to a stable object like the roof of a box each of them is applying half of its force on the pully behind it and, half on the wall it is connected too.
So by either of those ways, we can increase the moment on the item we want to move without changing how hard we need to pull.

Years ago when I was young and skinny(er), I had opportunity to use a double snatch block and appear as if I was Hercules. My buddy and I did tree installations and had to load an 800 pound tree w/ it’s dirt ball into the back of a pick up truck. We had a short ramp and cart, but it was still way too heavy to move. We could not budge the load. The nurseryman who sold us the tree said he was going to go get a tractor to load it. While he was gone, I pulled out a pair of double snatch blocks & rope and hooked it up to the cart and top of the truck bed. I tied the rope around me and went in the other direction and pulled with body weight and legs. We loaded the truck with the tree no problem. We then disassembled the snatch block and rope and put them in the truck. The guy with the tractor showed up only to find the tree already in the back of the truck. His jaw hit the floor. I usually explain the first pulley array you showed with conservation of energy. The distance you pull one end gets divided by the amount of ropes going up from the load, as they all  shorten the same amount. This means the distance is smaller, while the energy stays the same, so because of E=F*d , with constant E and smaller d, F will have to get bigger.

So...in high school, I did a science fair experiment using leverage and archimedes's compound pulley setup to lift my truck off the ground.

It started with just a lot of 45lb weights and ballooned into the truck lift at the actual fair. I had a crane company donate a crane for the day and I used a few multi pulley snatch blocks provided by the crane company to not only lift my truck, but do it with only my self as the lifting force.

In true Archimedes style...everyone was beyond impressed.

What helped me grasp where the mechanical advantage comes from when using pulleys is the conservation of work (maybe I should say energy), i.e. force times displacement, but I'm not sure about the technicalities. Correct me if I'm wrong: to pull up a weigth you have to balance gravity (and add some little more), but if you want to exert less force, say 1/nth, you need the rope you're pulling to travel n times as far as the height the weight gets from the ground. For example, if you pull one meter of rope, but the weight rises of just 50 centimeters (by using just one snatch block), you are applying a force F that is just half of what would normally take, because the work done by you and the one done by gravity G must be balanced:

F * 1m = G * 0.5m; F = 0.5G

An intuative way for me to understand it is that you must pull twice the length of rope when you add a second pulley.

With your jeep example where the winch is directly tied to the tree your rope is 1x long. When it goes around the snach block and back to the jeep, it becomes 2x long and all of it must be reeled in to move the jeep that distance.

I like that when you're talking to Jeff, your accent kicks in. You sound like a regular guy in the video until you start talking to another southerner, then you're twangin left and right all of a sudden. Same thing happened to me all the time when I was going to school in Texas. Grew up in the Pacific Northwest, didn't have any accent at all, but when I met a real Texan's Texan, I'd subconsciously put on an accent so they'd treat me like one of their own.

I remember once I was on someone's property (unbeknownst to me) when the guy comes riding up on his horse with a rifle in his hands, said "what are you boys doin on my land?" to us. I responded in the most Texas accent ever, responded "Sorry sir we didn't realize we were on private property. We're from UT, out here looking into a report of some sorta parasite that's been livin' in the streams and killin' cattle." The guy clearly figured me for a good old boy, sounded surprised about the parasite, told us we were fine to be on his property "so long as you keep me informed about this here parasite". There was no parasite, we were out there looking for lizards, but the quick thinking and the thickly laid on accent really did the trick.
